A Radiant Nuclear Resource

The Space Nuclear Opportunity

The next frontier of space exploration runs on nuclear power. The United States is in a race to deploy fission reactors on the Moon by 2030 — and the business development window is open right now.

Active Opportunities Agency Guide Why Radiant

Image: NASA Apollo 8 "Earthrise" (1968) — Public Domain

⚡ Why Space Needs Nuclear Power

Solar power has taken humanity far, but the next phase of space exploration demands something more. Nuclear fission is the only technology that can reliably power humanity's permanent presence beyond Earth. This is exactly why Radiant was founded.

The Lunar Night Problem

The Moon experiences 14-day nights where solar panels are useless. Permanently shadowed craters — where water ice exists — never see sunlight. Nuclear provides continuous power regardless of lighting conditions.

Mars Dust Storms

Global dust storms on Mars can block sunlight for months. The Opportunity rover was killed by a 2018 dust storm. Nuclear reactors operate regardless of atmospheric conditions — a reality that drove Radiant's founding vision.

Power Density

To power a lunar base with solar would require 3 football fields of panels. Radiant's Kaleidos microreactor fits in a shipping container and provides the same power for 10+ years without refueling.

Persistent Operations

Military and commercial satellites need reliable power for decades. Nuclear enables stealth operations (no large solar arrays), deep space missions, and always-on infrastructure.

The Math is Simple

1 kg of uranium contains the same energy as 3 million kg of coal. For deep space, where every kilogram costs $10,000+ to launch, nuclear is the only answer — and Radiant is building the reactors to make it happen.

⏰ The 2026-2030 Critical Window

After 50 years without a new US reactor design tested, space nuclear is suddenly happening. The next four years will determine who leads this market for decades. Radiant is positioned at the center of this transformation.

Year Milestone Significance
2026 DOME Testing Begins, NASA FSP Phase 2 Awards First US microreactor tests in 50+ years; major contracts awarded
2027 Radiant DOME Test, FSP Hardware Development Proof of commercial microreactor technology
2028 Project Pele Operational, Army Janus Deadline First DoD microreactors demonstrate military viability
2030 NASA Lunar Reactor Deployment Goal US nuclear power on the Moon — Artemis enabled
⚠

The Geopolitical Imperative

Russia and China signed an MOU in May 2025 to jointly develop nuclear power for the International Lunar Research Station (ILRS), targeting 2033-2035 deployment. The US cannot afford to cede this strategic capability.

A multi-agency, multi-billion dollar ecosystem is forming around space nuclear power. Understanding the players and programs is essential for strategic positioning — and Radiant is actively engaged across this entire ecosystem.

💡 Why This Resource Exists

The space nuclear microreactor market is emerging rapidly — but the business development landscape is fragmented and complex. Multiple federal agencies, overlapping programs, diverse contract vehicles, and evolving technical requirements create a challenging environment for companies seeking to participate in this transformational sector.

Radiant Nuclear built this resource to consolidate the critical information needed to navigate this landscape effectively. As a company actively engaged across NASA, DOE, DARPA, DIU, and DoD programs, we've developed deep institutional knowledge of how space nuclear opportunities emerge, evolve, and get awarded. This hub represents that knowledge, organized for action.

Whether you're tracking active solicitations, understanding agency priorities, learning the technical foundations, or developing capture strategies — this resource provides the comprehensive foundation required for effective business development in space nuclear power.

Radiant is committed to advancing the entire space nuclear ecosystem. We believe that consolidated, accessible information accelerates the industry's growth and strengthens US leadership in this strategically vital domain. This resource reflects that commitment.

Radiant's Perspective

  • Active across all major programs — FSP, DOME, DIU ANPI
  • Deep agency relationships — NASA, DOE, DoD, DARPA
  • $500M+ raised — Validated technology and approach
  • First-mover positioning — Space nuclear microreactors
  • Institutional BD knowledge — Captured in this resource

📚 Contract Types Explained

Understanding contract vehicles is critical for positioning. Each type serves different purposes and requires different approaches.

Type Full Name Purpose Typical Value Best For
RFI Request for Information Market research, shapes future RFPs. No contract yet. N/A Early positioning, requirement shaping
BAA Broad Agency Announcement R&D funding in loosely defined areas. White paper first. $100K - $50M Breakthrough concepts, startups
OTA Other Transaction Authority Fast prototyping without FAR compliance. Startup-friendly. $500K - $100M Rapid hardware demos
CSO Commercial Solutions Opening DIU's OTA variant. Near-commercial tech acquisition. $1M - $20M VC-backed companies
FAR RFP Federal Acquisition Regulation RFP Traditional full procurement. Heavy compliance required. $10M - $1B+ Production programs, primes
IDIQ Indefinite Delivery/Quantity Pre-qualified vendor pool, task orders issued later. Varies by order Ongoing services, established vendors
SBIR/STTR Small Business Innovation Research Small business R&D funding, 3-phase ladder to production. $150K - $2M Startups, small businesses
CRADA Cooperative R&D Agreement Partner with national labs on R&D. Shared IP terms. Varies Lab access, testing

🔔 How to Set Up Contract Alerts

Follow this checklist to ensure you never miss an opportunity. Smart companies treat RFIs like mini-proposals.

  • 1. Register on SAM.gov

    Create account at sam.gov. Get your UEI (Unique Entity ID) and CAGE code. Required for all federal contracts. This is mandatory before you can bid on anything.

  • 2. Set Up SAM.gov Saved Searches

    Keywords: "space nuclear", "fission surface power", "nuclear thermal", "reactor", "HALEU", "cislunar power", "space power", "energy conversion". Enable email notifications for all saved searches.

  • 3. Register on SBIR.gov

    Create account at sbir.gov. Subscribe to topic areas: nuclear, space technology, power systems, thermal management, advanced materials.

  • 4. Monitor DARPA Weekly (No Auto-Alerts)

    DARPA doesn't have automated alerts - manually check DARPA opportunities every Monday. Watch for TTO and DSO BAAs.

  • 5. Follow NASA FSP Program

    Bookmark NASA Glenn FSP page. Industry days are announced before SAM.gov postings. Attend all industry days and webinars.

  • 6. Register for DSIP (DoD SBIR/STTR)

    Defense SBIR/STTR Innovation Portal at dodsbirsttr.mil for DoD proposal submission system access.

  • 7. Watch DOE BAA Schedule

    DOE releases BAAs first Wednesday monthly. Check energy.gov and SAM.gov. Keywords: DOE nuclear space power, reactor, HALEU.

  • 8. Register on NASA NSPIRES

    Create account at nspires.nasaprs.com for NASA research opportunities and NOIs (Notices of Intent).

🌑 NASA - Fission Surface Power Program

NASA's primary vehicle for lunar nuclear power. FSP is a formal technology-development program led by NASA in partnership with DOE.

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

2030 Goal: Lunar Surface Reactor

NASA declared intent to put a nuclear reactor on the Moon by Q1 FY2030. Recently signed MOU with DOE solidifies collaboration and advances deployment of nuclear reactors on the Moon and in orbit. The system will provide at least 40 kWe - enough to continuously run 30 households for ten years.

The Fission Surface Power (FSP) initiative is a collaborative effort between DOE, NASA, and Idaho National Laboratory to develop and demonstrate a nuclear fission power system capable of supporting long-duration missions on the Moon and Mars. FSP is managed through NASA Glenn Research Center and sits within the Moon to Mars Program Office in the Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate.

Why NASA Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Primary US government customer for lunar/Mars nuclear power
  • Sets technical requirements that shape industry designs
  • Controls Artemis integration pathway
  • Partners with DOE on nuclear safety and testing
  • Budget authority for space power technology

Recent Strategic Priorities

  • Artemis program lunar return by 2030
  • Sustainable lunar presence requiring reliable power
  • Mars preparation with nuclear systems
  • National security in space (MOU with DOE)
  • Commercial partnerships for cost reduction

💡 Use Cases for Space Micro-Reactors

Lunar Surface Operations

  • Power during 14-day lunar nights (solar impossible)
  • Permanently shadowed crater operations (water ice)
  • Artemis habitat power (40+ kWe continuous)
  • ISRU processing (oxygen/water extraction)
  • Science instrument power

Beyond the Moon

  • Mars surface power (dust storms block solar)
  • Deep space missions (reduced solar flux)
  • Cislunar infrastructure support
  • National security applications
  • Long-duration crewed missions

⚙ CONTRACTING PROCESS: How to Win NASA Contracts

▼

Acquisition Process (Step-by-Step)

  1. Industry Day / RFI Release NASA signals interest, gathers market intel
  2. Draft Solicitation Industry reviews and provides feedback
  3. Final RFP/BAA Release Formal solicitation on SAM.gov
  4. Q&A Period Typically 2-4 weeks for clarifications
  5. Proposal Submission Technical, Management, Cost volumes
  6. Evaluation 60-180 days depending on complexity
  7. Award / Negotiations May include competitive range discussions

Timeline (RFI to Award)

  • Study contracts: 6-12 months from RFI
  • Phase 1 concepts: 12-18 months
  • Major hardware: 18-36 months

Contract Vehicles NASA Uses

  • Space Act Agreements Unfunded/funded partnerships, flexible IP
  • SBIR/STTR $150K Phase I, $1-2M Phase II
  • BAAs Research-focused, white paper first
  • Competed Contracts Full FAR-based procurement
  • OTAs Less common but available for prototypes
  • Tipping Point Public-private cost-share for flight demos

Evaluation Criteria

Technical (typically 50-60%)

  • Technical approach soundness
  • Innovation vs risk balance
  • Path to demonstration
  • Safety methodology

Management & Cost (40-50%)

  • Team qualifications
  • Schedule realism
  • Cost realism (not lowest price)
  • Past performance

How to Get on NASA's Radar

  • Attend Industry Days Glenn Research Center hosts FSP events
  • Submit thoughtful RFI responses These shape requirements
  • Publish technical papers NASA watches conferences
  • Request PM briefings Email program managers directly
  • Partner with NASA labs Glenn, Marshall, JPL for space power
  • Join working groups Nuclear systems, surface power forums

Teaming Strategy

When to Prime

  • Study contracts <$5M
  • You own the core technology
  • SBIR/STTR (must be small business)
  • Reactor subsystem specifically

When to Sub

  • Full system integration contracts
  • Flight hardware programs
  • Contracts >$25M
  • When prime brings launch/spacecraft

Win Themes for NASA

  • Supports Artemis timeline (2030 goal)
  • Scalable from lunar to Mars
  • Commercial viability / cost reduction
  • Launch safety addressed
  • DOE lab partnership in place

Red Flags That Kill Proposals

  • No nuclear expertise on team
  • Ignoring launch safety requirements
  • Unrealistic schedules
  • No path to flight qualification
  • Overreliance on unproven tech
  • No DOE/national lab access

📈 ACTIVE PROGRAMS & Opportunities

▼

Fission Surface Power (FSP) Program

Status: Phase 2 solicitation expected early 2026

Goal: 100 kWe lunar reactor using Brayton cycle, operational by 2030. NASA FSP + DOE partnership is the primary pathway for US lunar nuclear power.

Budget Cycles

  • Fiscal year starts October 1
  • Budget requests submitted February
  • End-of-year spending surge (Aug-Sept)
  • Multi-year funding for major programs

Typical Award Sizes

  • Concept studies: $5M (Phase 1)
  • DEEP awards: $5M (Radiant, Westinghouse received Nov 2024)
  • Prototype development: $50-200M
  • Flight systems: $200M+
💡

Pro Tip: Industry Days

NASA centers (especially Glenn) often post industry days before official SAM.gov releases. Attend all webinars and industry engagement events - these are early signals before contracts are posted.

🤖 DARPA - Breakthrough R&D

High-risk, high-reward R&D funding. DARPA is friendlier to startups and innovative approaches than traditional defense procurement. Key office: Tactical Technology Office (TTO).

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

What DARPA Does

Focus is on producible, cost-effective nuclear reactors - not bespoke designs suited for one-time demonstrations. Startup-friendly evaluation. They love radical miniaturization, fast deployment, unconventional architectures, and autonomy.

DARPA (Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency) is the Pentagon's high-risk, high-reward R&D arm. Unlike traditional defense procurement, DARPA welcomes startups and innovative approaches. The mission of the Tactical Technology Office (TTO) is to reimagine every aspect of military hardware design, development, test, manufacture, and sustainment with a focus on rapid, affordable, and scalable deployment.

Why DARPA Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Leads breakthrough space technology development
  • Startup-friendly contracting (BAAs, OTAs)
  • Direct PM access - can shape programs
  • On-Orbit Nuclear Power initiative active
  • Bridges R&D to operational systems

Recent Strategic Priorities

  • On-orbit nuclear power systems
  • Producible, cost-effective reactors
  • Rapid deployment capabilities
  • Direct radiation-to-electricity (Rads to Watts)
  • Cislunar operations support

Nuclear thermal propulsion demonstration cancelled due to cost/benefit analysis. SpaceX launch cost decreases changed the calculus. Knowledge transferred to NASA. On-Orbit Nuclear Power is now the active program.

⚙ CONTRACTING PROCESS: How to Win DARPA Contracts

▼

DARPA BAA Process (Step-by-Step)

  1. BAA Published Posted on SAM.gov and DARPA website
  2. White Paper Submission 5-8 page concept (4-6 weeks)
  3. Evaluation DARPA PMs review (2-4 weeks)
  4. Invitation to Submit If selected, full proposal requested
  5. Full Proposal 30-60 pages technical + cost (4-6 weeks)
  6. Negotiations Often iterative with PM
  7. Award Total: 4-8 months from BAA
💡

DARPA Secret: Program Managers Have Discretion

DARPA PMs can shape programs around compelling ideas. Brief them early, understand their technical interests, and your concept may become their next program.

Contract Vehicles DARPA Uses

  • BAA (Broad Agency Announcement) Primary vehicle, phased awards
  • OTA (Other Transaction) For prototypes, very flexible
  • SBIR/STTR Small business pathway
  • Cooperative Agreements When cost-share required

What DARPA Cares About

They Love:

  • Novel technical approaches
  • Quantified risk reduction
  • Credible team (named individuals)
  • Realistic test plans
  • Transition path to operations

They Hate:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Compliance theater
  • Vague promises
  • Past primes on every contract
  • PowerPoint engineering

How to Get on DARPA's Radar

  • Read BAAs weekly Check DARPA website every week
  • Attend Proposers Days Always attend when announced
  • Request PM meetings Email directly with 1-page concept
  • Respond to RFIs On-Orbit Nuclear Power RFI currently active
  • Workshop participation Upcoming: March 31 - April 1, 2026

White Paper Structure (5-8 pages)

  1. Problem Statement What DARPA problem are you solving?
  2. Technical Approach Novel aspect, why it works
  3. Key Innovations What's new vs state of art?
  4. Team Named individuals, relevant experience
  5. Risks & Mitigations Be honest, show you've thought it through
  6. Schedule & Cost ROM Rough order of magnitude

Win Themes for DARPA

  • "Producible, cost-effective" Not bespoke one-time demos
  • Dual-use potential (civil + military)
  • Clear phase gates with go/no-go criteria
  • Transition partner identified
  • DOE/lab partnership for nuclear

🏭 Department of War (DoW) - Military Microreactor Programs

The Department of War is aggressively pursuing microreactor technology for energy resilience at military installations. Key programs include Janus (Army bases) and Project Pele (mobile reactor prototype).

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

Executive Order 14299 Mandate

Signed May 2025, EO 14299 "Deploying Advanced Nuclear Reactor Technologies for National Security" directs DoW to begin operation of an Army-regulated nuclear reactor at a domestic military installation no later than September 30, 2028.

Why DoW Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Largest procurement budget for microreactors
  • Accelerated timelines (2028 deadline)
  • Validates commercial microreactor technology
  • Creates pathway for space-rated designs
  • Terrestrial deployments de-risk space applications

Key Organizations

  • OUSD R&E Oversees technology strategy
  • Strategic Capabilities Office (SCO) Project Pele lead
  • Army Office of Energy Initiatives Janus program
  • Defense Innovation Unit (DIU) ANPI program
  • Air Force ANPI program partner

🎯 Major Programs

Janus Program (Army)

  • Goal: Up to 12 microreactors by July 4, 2026
  • Sites: 9 candidate locations identified
  • Power: 1-20 MWe per unit
  • Model: Commercially owned & operated
  • Led by Army Secretary Daniel Driscoll

Project Pele (SCO)

  • Contractor: BWXT
  • Power: 1.5 MWe mobile prototype
  • Fuel: TRISO particles
  • Testing: INL, begins 2027
  • Deadline: Operational by Sep 2028
  • Transportable in shipping containers

9 Candidate Janus Sites

InstallationLocationNotes

Fort HoodTexasLargest active-duty armored post

Fort WainwrightAlaskaExtreme cold, grid isolation

Space Nuclear Connection

DoW microreactor programs validate technology that directly applies to space applications. Successful terrestrial deployment of TRISO-fueled, helium-cooled designs (like Radiant's) creates credibility for NASA FSP and other space nuclear programs.

🌠 Space Force / SpaceWERX

Space Force mixes traditional DoD acquisition with rapid innovation vehicles. SpaceWERX is their innovation arm running SBIR/STTR, challenges, and OTAs.

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

⚠

SBIR/STTR Program Status Update

As of October 1, 2025, SBIR/STTR program authorization has expired. New activity is paused; ongoing awards remain valid. The next solicitation is expected to open on the first Wednesday following congressional reauthorization. Monitor spacewerx.us for updates.

The U.S. Space Force is the newest military branch, established December 2019. SpaceWERX is their innovation arm (under AFRL since August 2021), executing an annual $457M budget with 40+ personnel. Since alignment with AFRL, SpaceWERX has executed 1,106 contracts worth over $897M. The AFRL Space Vehicles Directorate at Kirtland AFB is the nation's center of excellence for military space science and technology R&D.

Why Space Force Matters for Nuclear

  • AFRL JETSON program for space nuclear power
  • SPAR Institute ($35M for nuclear propulsion)
  • SpaceWERX fast-track innovation pathway
  • Cislunar superiority requirements
  • High-power sensor and payload needs

Recent Strategic Priorities

  • Power-hungry sensors and payloads
  • Cislunar domain awareness
  • Resilient space architectures
  • Denied-environment operations
  • Rapid deployment capability

👁 National Reconnaissance Office (NRO) - Intelligence Satellites

The NRO designs, builds, and operates US reconnaissance satellites. As satellite constellations grow and missions become more demanding, nuclear power may enable capabilities solar cannot.

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Relevance

▼

🌐 Agency Background

Growing Satellite Constellation

The NRO announced plans to quadruple its satellite fleet and increase signals/images by 10x within the decade. Nearly 200 satellites now in orbit, making it the largest government-operated satellite fleet. This expansion creates potential demand for advanced power systems.

Why NRO Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Operates largest US government satellite fleet
  • Power-hungry sensor payloads
  • Long-duration missions in various orbits
  • High-power radar and communication needs
  • Space domain awareness requirements

NRO Space Nuclear Relevance

  • GEO operations: Deep space positioning
  • Active sensing: High power for radar
  • Persistence: Years without degradation
  • Stealth: Smaller signature than solar
  • Resilience: Works during eclipses

🎯 Current Activities

Proliferated Architecture

  • Nearly 200 satellites in LEO constellation
  • 150+ satellites deployed in 2 years
  • 12+ launches planned for 2025
  • Joint operations with Space Force & NGA

Space Force Partnership

  • SpaceX $739M launch contract (2025)
  • Joint NROL missions
  • Shared infrastructure
  • Separate surveillance satellite paths
💡

Space Nuclear Opportunity

While NRO hasn't announced specific nuclear power programs, the December 2025 "Space Superiority" Executive Order mandates nuclear reactors in orbit. As the largest operator of government satellites, NRO may become a customer for space nuclear power systems.

Organization

  • Part of Intelligence Community
  • Reports to DoD and DNI
  • Headquartered in Chantilly, VA
  • Director: Dr. Christopher Scolese

Key Links

  • NRO Main
  • NRO Acquisition
  • NRO Launches

⚙ Defense Innovation Unit (DIU)

Fast, flexible commercial acquisition. DIU runs Commercial Solutions Openings (CSO) that can award within 60-90 days. Perfect for VC-backed startups with commercial products.

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

DIU's Unique Value: Speed + Transition

DIU doesn't just buy prototypes they pre-identify DoD transition partners who will take the technology to production. This solves the "valley of death" problem. Fast commercial technology acquisition - often awarding within 60-90 days.

The Defense Innovation Unit (DIU) reports directly to the Secretary of Defense and accelerates the DoD's adoption of commercial technology. In FY2024, DIU received nearly $1 billion from the National Defense Authorization Act. DIU uses Commercial Solutions Openings (CSO) and Other Transaction Authority (OTA) for rapid prototyping. The Janus Program for Army microreactors is modeled after NASA's successful Commercial Orbital Transportation Services (COTS) program.

Why DIU Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Janus Program for Army microreactors
  • Fastest DoD contracting (60-90 days)
  • VC-backed startup friendly
  • Pre-identifies transition partners
  • Milestone-based contracting model

What DIU Looks For

  • Commercial traction Revenue or funded customers
  • Existing product Not paper concepts
  • Dual-use Commercial AND military
  • Scalable Can meet DoD quantities
  • Fundable VC backing shows validation

💰 Recent Major Contracts Awarded

DateProgramDetails
Nov 2025Janus Program AOIArea of Interest released - microreactors for 9 Army bases (due Dec 15, 2025)
Aug 2025DIU/RadiantFirst mass-manufactured microreactor to military base contract
Aug 2025ANPI Selections8 companies selected for Advanced Nuclear Power for Installations (incl. Oklo, Radiant)
Jun 2024Janus Program LaunchArmy-DIU partnership announced for commercial microreactors
🔥

Executive Order 14299 Deadline: September 2028

President Trump signed EO 14299 (May 2025) directing DoD to commence operation of an Army-regulated nuclear reactor at a domestic military installation by September 30, 2028. This is driving urgent DIU activity.

💡 Use Cases for Space Micro-Reactors

DIU focuses on terrestrial military microreactors, but this work directly enables space nuclear through supply chain and technology development:

Direct Military Applications

  • Forward operating base power
  • Remote installation resilience
  • Energy independence from adversaries
  • Rapid deployment capability
  • Grid vulnerability reduction

Space Nuclear Spillover

  • HALEU fuel supply chain development
  • Regulatory pathway establishment
  • Manufacturing scale-up
  • Reactor design validation
  • Technology/talent pipeline

🔥 Janus Program - Army Nuclear Microreactors

⚙ CONTRACTING PROCESS: How to Win DIU Contracts

▼

CSO Process (Step-by-Step)

  1. CSO Posted Problem statement on DIU website
  2. Solution Brief Submitted 5-10 page PDF pitch deck style
  3. DIU Review 2-4 weeks
  4. Pitch Day In-person or virtual presentation
  5. Prototype OTA Award 60-90 days total from CSO
  6. Prototype Execution 12-24 months typical
  7. Production Transition Follow-on to DoD customer

Solution Brief Structure

Think pitch deck, not government proposal. DIU wants:

  • Problem/Solution fit How you solve their specific problem
  • Product description What exists today
  • Commercial relevance Non-DoD customers
  • Team Founders + key technical leads
  • Prototype plan What you'll deliver in 12-24 months
  • Cost estimate Rough pricing
💡

Why DIU Matters for Space Nuclear

Terrestrial nuclear work through DIU (like Janus) influences availability of nuclear technology, fuel, regulatory processes, and supply chains that can support space nuclear power development. VC-backed reactor startups are particularly well-suited for DIU's CSO process.

📈 ACTIVE PROGRAMS & Opportunities

▼

🔥 HOT: Janus Program - Army Nuclear Microreactors

DIU released a solicitation for commercially-made "advanced nuclear power technologies" for Army installations. The Army has executed a MOA with DIU to utilize its CSO process and OTA for the Janus Program.

  • 9 Army bases identified for potential deployment
  • Joint effort with DOE
  • Iterative prototyping via OTAs
  • Supports Executive Order 14299
  • Deadline: September 2028

"DIU is ready and excited to leverage our rapid CSO process to execute the Janus Program... This collaboration will deliver advanced nuclear energy to Army installations."
- Dr. Andrew Higier, DIU Energy Portfolio Director

  • Fort Wainwright, Alaska

⚡ Department of Energy / National Labs

Any real reactor touches DOE facilities. DOE lab relationships are existential for reactor companies. Critical for anything involving actual reactor physics, fuel, or nuclear material testing.

📍 OVERVIEW: Mission, Structure & Contacts

▼

🌐 Agency Background

Why DOE Matters

Partner with them to test fuel forms, run safety analysis, irradiate materials, qualify components, and license launch packages. DOE + NASA collaborative initiative on power systems for lunar + Mars missions.

The DOE Office of Nuclear Energy oversees all US nuclear R&D. Idaho National Laboratory (INL) is the lead for DOE Space Reactor Program and home to the world's first microreactor test beds (DOME and LOTUS). The National Reactor Innovation Center (NRIC) at INL accelerates deployment of advanced reactors by providing industry access to world-class capabilities. DOE lab relationships are existential for any company building real reactors.

Why DOE Matters for Space Nuclear

  • DOME facility for microreactor testing

🎯 Key Programs to Track

DOME Facility at INL

  • World's first microreactor test bed
  • Construction complete: March 2026
  • Reactor installs: December 2026
  • First test: Radiant Kaleidos, Summer 2026
  • Up to 20 MWth capacity
  • Why it matters: First new US reactor design tested in 50+ years

Project Pele

  • DoD mobile microreactor (1.5 MWe)
  • Contractor: BWXT
  • Operation deadline: Sep 2028
  • Demonstrates transportable nuclear
  • Why it matters: Proves mobile reactor viability

NRIC Programs

  • FEEED - Front-End Engineering & Experiment Design (~$1.5M)
  • DEEP - Detailed Engineering & Experiment Planning (~$5M)
  • LOTUS - Second microreactor test bed

HALEU Supply Program

  • DOE allocations to multiple companies
  • Radiant allocation: April 2025
  • US producer: Centrus (Piketon, OH)
  • Critical for space nuclear (high-enriched fuel)

📈 ACTIVE PROGRAMS & Opportunities

▼

DOME Facility at INL - First Microreactor Tests

Construction complete March 2026. First test: Radiant Kaleidos, Summer 2026 - the first new US reactor design tested in 50+ years. Westinghouse eVinci NTR also selected. Timeline accelerated 11 months from original Feb 2027 target.

Key Active Programs

Project Pele

DoD mobile microreactor (1.5 MWe). BWXT building prototype. Operation deadline: September 2028. Demonstrates transportable nuclear power.

NRIC

National Reactor Innovation Center provides testing infrastructure and regulatory support for advanced reactor developers.

HALEU Supply Status

DOE has allocated HALEU to several companies including Radiant (Apr 2025). US producers: Centrus (Piketon, OH) ramping production. Critical for space nuclear applications requiring high-enriched fuel.

🛠 Department of War (DoW) SBIR/STTR

DoW uses the Broad Agency Announcement (BAA) funding mechanism to procure basic and applied research via issuing topics for scientific study directed towards advancing the state-of-the-art.

How DoW Works

  • BAAs released first Wednesday of every month
  • Some topics released under Commercial Solutions Opening (CSO)
  • Three pre-scheduled SBIR/STTR BAAs/CSOs per fiscal year
  • Topics seek innovative solutions from small businesses
  • Usually in response to national security challenges

Key Links

  • DoD SBIR/STTR Opportunities
  • SBIR.gov - All Topics
  • SBIR.gov - By Agency
DoD SBIR/STTR Portal → SBIR.gov Topics →

🛡 Related DoD Terrestrial Programs

Not strictly "space" but show how DoD nuclear efforts spill over into space-related capability ecosystems. These terrestrial efforts often influence availability of nuclear technology, fuel, regulatory processes, and supply chains that can support space nuclear power development later on.

Project Pele

DoD mobile microreactor development for remote bases (~1-5 MWe). Demonstrates transportable nuclear power for forward operating bases. Influences availability of nuclear technology, fuel, and supply chains for future space applications.

Janus Program

U.S. Army initiative to install microreactors on 9 identified installations. DIU partnership using CSO/OTA process. Joint effort with DOE under Executive Order 14299. Could cross over into broader DoD nuclear tech supply chains that support space nuclear.

🔔 SBIR.gov - Cross-Agency SBIR/STTR Search

This site lets you search ALL federal agencies' small business innovation solicitations (DARPA, DoD, DOE, NASA, NSF, etc.) in one place. You can subscribe to topics and receive email notifications.

🕵 Other Defense & Intel Stakeholders

Secondary stakeholders that become relevant as space nuclear programs mature and require broader DoD buy-in. Focus primary BD efforts on NASA, DARPA, Space Force, DIU, and DOE firstbut keep these organizations on your radar.

🛡 Missile Defense Agency (MDA)

Develops and deploys layered missile defense systems, including space-based sensor layers requiring high-power capabilities.

Why MDA Matters for Space Nuclear

  • Space-based sensor layer development (LEO constellation)
  • High-power radar and tracking needs
  • 24/7 persistent surveillance requirements
  • Golden Dome Initiative: Next-gen missile defense architecture

How to Engage

Watch for RFIs on high-power space systems. MDA coordinates with Space Force on space layer requirements.

MDA Business Portal | MDA Main Site

🎓 OUSD Research & Engineering

The "CTO of the Pentagon" - sets DoD-wide S&T priorities and oversees DARPA, DIU, and Strategic Capabilities Office. Critical for shaping requirements.

Why USD R&E Matters

  • Sets 14 Critical Technology Areas for DoD
  • Oversees DARPA, DIU, SCO - all key space nuclear players
  • Technology transition authority
  • DoD S&T budget priorities and roadmaps

How to Engage

Goal: Get space nuclear on the Critical Technology roadmap. Engage through DARPA/DIU relationships first.

CTO.mil | OUSD R&E Overview

🛰 Space Development Agency (SDA)

Rapidly fields proliferated LEO satellite constellations for transport, tracking, and custody layers. Part of Space Force since Oct 2022.

Why SDA Matters

  • PWSA: Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture
  • Hundreds of satellites in LEO - high ops tempo = power needs
  • 2-year spiral development cycles (Tranches)
  • Tranche 3: 2026 contract awards

Key Programs

  • Transport Layer: Data mesh network
  • Tracking Layer: Missile warning
  • Custody Layer: Fire control quality tracking

SDA Main Site | SDA Opportunities

🚀 Space Systems Command (SSC)

Space Force's primary acquisition arm. Manages major space programs and runs SSC Front Door innovation program for commercial engagement.

Why SSC Matters

  • Space Force primary acquisition command
  • $14B+ annual budget
  • Manages GPS, SBIRS, SDA oversight
  • HQ: Los Angeles Space Force Base

How to Engage

Front Door: SSC's commercial innovation portal - start here for Space Force entry. Also watch Tactically Responsive Space and Space Domain Awareness programs.

SSC Front Door | SSC Main Site

💡

Strategic Approach

These organizations become relevant as programs mature. Win contracts with primary stakeholders first (NASA FSP, AFRL JETSON, DIU microreactors), then expand relationships. MDA and SDA are where space nuclear power demand could grow significantly as their constellations require more capable power systems.

🚀 Radiant's Path to Space Nuclear Leadership

Terrestrial validation Military credibility Space dominance

The Strategy

Radiant is using terrestrial microreactors to validate the company, build government relationships, and prove production capability. But the goal has always been space. The Kaleidos program proves the technology works on Earth; the Moon, Mars, and orbit are the destination.

Radiant's Current Position (2026)

✅ Wins Already Secured

  • DIU/USAF Contract (Aug 2025) First mass-manufactured microreactor to military base
  • DOE HALEU Allocation (Apr 2025) Critical fuel supply secured
  • $300M+ Series D (Dec 2025) Capital to move fast
  • NASA FSP Phase 1 Participant Already in the conversation
  • DOE DEEP Award ($5M) Lab partnership established
  • DoD SBIR Phase 2 Defense credibility building
  • INL DOME Testing (2027) Kaleidos ground test scheduled

🎯 Why This Matters for Space

  • Military contract = government trust Proves Radiant can deliver to DoD standards
  • HALEU secured = supply chain solved Most competitors still waiting
  • Private capital = speed advantage Move faster than incumbent primes
  • FSP participation = seat at the table Already shaping requirements
  • Lab partnerships = test infrastructure Access to facilities others can't get
  • Production mindset = not bespoke Agencies want scalable, not one-offs

Key Leadership

Doug Bernauer

CEO & Founder

Vision: "Nuclear power can make life multi-solar." SpaceX heritage, understands how to move fast in aerospace.

Dr. Rita Baranwal

Chief Nuclear Officer

Former DOE Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Energy. Knows every decision-maker in government nuclear. Massive credibility asset.

⚡ Why Radiant Wins in Space

Kaleidos wasn't designed for spacebut its architecture translates better than competitors realize.

Kaleidos Specs Space Requirements

  • Helium coolant Works in vacuum, non-activating, no fluid management issues in microgravity
  • Compact form factor (70-tonne) Launch mass is existential; Radiant already optimizes for transportability
  • Zirconium hydride moderator Proprietary tech, proven physics, adaptable to space thermal environment
  • Autonomous operations DNA No astronaut maintenance; self-start, self-regulate, self-protect
  • Mass production mindset DARPA explicitly wants "producible, not bespoke" Radiant's entire philosophy

Radiant vs. Incumbent Advantages

  • vs. BWXT: BWXT is slow, government-paced, bespoke. Radiant moves at startup speed with private capital.
  • vs. Westinghouse: Focused on large terrestrial SMRs. Radiant built for portability from day one.
  • vs. Lockheed: They need a reactor partner. Radiant IS the reactor.
  • vs. Standard Nuclear: Still recovering from USNC bankruptcy. Radiant has momentum.
  • vs. Everyone: SpaceX + Blue Origin alumni understand launch constraints. Team knows aerospace.
💡

The Winning Statement

"We've already built and tested hardware, secured HALEU, won a military contract, and are partnered with DOE national labs. We're not a PowerPoint company." This puts Radiant in the top tier of any space nuclear proposal evaluation.

CRITICAL

DRACO cancelled, but DARPA still wants space nuclear. They're looking for new approaches.

HIGH

📈 The 5-Phase BD Roadmap

Space micro-reactors won't jump straight to billion-dollar buys. They move in a staircase: Market shaping → OTA prototypes → Ground demos → Flight test → FAR production.

0
Phase 0: Market Creation & Mission Shaping
Before programs exist. Create demand, define missions, influence requirements, unlock budgets.

Activities: White papers, lunar-night analyses, industry conferences, prime briefings, Hill engagement

Vehicles: Study contracts, SBIR Phase I, Concept BAAs

Output: "Nuclear required" narrative, draft requirements, agency champions

1
Phase 1: Concept & Risk Reduction
First technical money. Show space-adaptable reactor designs work on paper and in labs.

Activities: Space-variant core designs, thermal-vacuum modeling, autonomy concepts, launch safety strawmen

Vehicles: OTA prototypes, SBIR Phase II, BAAs

Output: Credible space reactor architecture, invitations to bigger demos

2
Phase 2: Integrated Ground Prototype
Full nuclear system on Earth. Run complete power system in test facilities.

Activities: Reactor hardware, control systems, power modules, safety packages, prime teaming

Vehicles: Large OTAs, Prototype BAAs ($5-25M)

Output: Government-validated reactor, "Reactor OEM" status

3
Phase 3: Flight Demonstration Mission
First real deployment in space. Launch and operate reactor in orbit or on surface.

Activities: Flight core delivery, fuel coordination, nuclear safety inputs, ops modeling

Vehicles: Hybrid OTA to FAR demo ($20-100M+)

Output: Flight heritage, default supplier positioning

4
Phase 4: Operational Procurement
Infrastructure, not experiments. Buy fleets and sustain them for decades. Multi-billion dollar programs.

Activities: Scale factories, secure HALEU supply, classified facilities, lifecycle ops

Vehicles: FAR-based production contracts, IDIQ vehicles

Output: Multi-billion-dollar programs, strategic-asset status

🏆 What Federal Wins Look Like

The ladder from early credibility to production procurement.

Win #1: SBIR/Study

$150K - $2M

  • Reactor core architecture studies
  • Heat-pipe cooled concepts
  • Shielding mass optimization
  • Autonomous startup/shutdown logic

Result: Gets you into working groups, PM relationships, acquisition planning docs

Win #2: Subsystem Contract

$5M - $25M

  • Nuclear island design
  • Fuel mockups and neutronics
  • Thermal vacuum tests
  • Shielding qualification

Result: Ties to Artemis infrastructure, flight requirements, "program supplier" status

Win #3: Demo Program

$20M - $100M+

  • Integrated reactor prototype
  • Autonomous operations
  • Deployment robotics
  • Long-life endurance tests

Result: Bridge from R&D to Program of Record. Nine-figure follow-ons become plausible.

🔍 What Agencies Actually Evaluate

Across DARPA, Space Force, NASA, and DOE, proposals rise or fall on these criteria:

Technical Criteria

  • Clear mission relevance
  • Technical novelty plus realism
  • Credible scaling path
  • Safety and regulatory awareness
  • Test infrastructure access
  • Schedule discipline
  • Transition plan to operational use

Nuclear-Specific Must-Haves

  • DOE lab access/partnerships
  • Fuel pathway understanding
  • Launch-safety literacy
  • Export-control awareness
  • Named nuclear engineers on team
  • Non-nuclear prototype data
  • Regulatory pathway knowledge

💡 The Winning Statement

"We've already built and tested a non-nuclear prototype and are partnered with a national lab."

This puts you in the top tier of any proposal evaluation.

📝 Model RFI Response Structure

When agencies ask "How would industry provide nuclear power in space?" - use this structure:

Section 1: Executive Summary (1-2 paragraphs)

▼

Propose a scalable space micro-reactor architecture derived from terrestrial systems, optimized for vacuum cooling, autonomous operations, and sub-critical launch safety. Keep it concise - this is your hook.

Section 2: Mission Applications

▼
  • Lunar surface: 40-250 kWe (baseline target)
  • Orbital platforms: 20-100 kWe
  • Mars habitats: 250 kWe+
  • Defense ISR platforms
  • ISRU oxygen plants

Section 3: Technical Approach

▼
  • Moderated HALEU core
  • Heat-pipe or gas cooling (e.g., helium)
  • Radiator panels for heat rejection
  • Directional shielding strategy
  • Brayton/Stirling power conversion
  • Autonomous control systems

Section 4: Development Plan

▼
  • Year 1: Design & modeling
  • Year 2: Sub-scale hardware
  • Year 3-4: Ground prototype
  • Key milestones and decision gates

Section 5: Safety & Launch Considerations

▼
  • Sub-critical launch state
  • Impact survivability design
  • Regulatory review process understanding
  • UN treaty compliance
  • Presidential approval pathway

Sections 6-8: Teaming, Cost ROM, Why Us

▼
  • Teaming: Reactor OEM + prime integrator + national labs
  • Cost ROM: Concept study $5-15M, Ground demo $75-200M
  • Differentiators: Mobile-reactor experience, moderator IP, autonomy focus, private capital backing

Positioning & Teaming

  • Your Role: Reactor OEM, core designer, autonomy provider
  • Prime Integrator: TBD spacecraft company
  • National Lab: Fuel & safety partnership
  • Competitors: Other reactor startups, defense primes w/ nuclear groups

Differentiators & Win Themes

  • Lowest mass/kW ratio
  • Fastest path to demo

  • Autonomy stack maturity

BD Actions & Gates

  • Monthly agency meetings
  • Quarterly white papers
  • Conference presence
  • Prime MOUs signed
  • Included in draft RFP language

💡 The Core Truth of Defense BD

Defense BD = Create Programs, Not Just Chase Them

By the time an RFP hits SAM.gov, winning vendors have already been shaping the conversation for 12-24 months.

Smart companies show up early, brief program managers, and submit thoughtful RFI responses that quietly steer requirements toward what they can deliver. The RFP isn't the starting lineit's the midpoint.

Commercial Sales vs Defense BD

CommercialDefense/Space
Quarterly closeMulti-year pursuit
Pricing focusedBudget + policy focused
Buyer = CIO/CTOBuyer = Program Office + Congress
Demo ContractDemo Budget RFP Contract
Direct negotiationFormal evaluation criteria

The Pre-RFP Advantage

  • 12-24 months out: Begin capture planning
  • Monitor signals: Sources Sought, RFIs, agency forecasts
  • Engage draft RFPs: Comment on requirements, shape language
  • Build relationships: End users, PMs, requirements officers
  • Publish thought leadership: White papers, analyses, trade studies
  • Attend everything: Industry days, workshops, conferences

⚔ Who Radiant Is Competing Against (2025-2026)

Know the competition. The space nuclear market has three tiersand Radiant has advantages against each.

💡

Key Market Shift: DRACO Cancelled (May 2025)

DARPA cancelled its flagship program citing declining ROI as SpaceX reduced launch costs. This is good for Radiant: the incumbent BWXT/Lockheed team lost their flagship program, and agencies are now looking for faster, more cost-effective approachesexactly what Radiant offers.

Tier 1: Established Nuclear Primes

BWX Technologies (BWXT)
DOMINANT

Position: Sole manufacturer of naval nuclear reactors. Strongest government relationships.

  • DRACO Phase 2 reactor design ($499M program)
  • Project Pele frontrunner (1.5 MWe gas-cooled)
  • NASA NTP fuel development contracts
  • HALEU fuel fabrication capability

Strategy: Leverage government trust; fuel/reactor subsystems as subcontractor to aerospace primes

✅ Radiant's edge: BWXT is slow and bespoke. Government-paced. Radiant moves at startup speed with private capital and production mindset.

Lockheed Martin
PRIME

Position: Lead prime contractor for major space nuclear programs.

  • DRACO program lead (with BWXT as sub)
  • JETSON contract ($33.7M reactor design)
  • NASA Fission Surface Power (with BWXT, Creare)

Strategy: Prime contractor role; nuclear specialists as subs; leverage Artemis positioning

✅ Radiant's edge: Lockheed needs a reactor partner. They're not a competitorthey're a teaming target. Radiant IS the reactor; Lockheed is the integrator.

Westinghouse Government Services
EMERGING

Position: Major nuclear developer with commercial/government dual-track.

  • JETSON contract ($16.9M)
  • NASA-DOE Fission Surface Power Phase 2 (Jan 2025)
  • eVinci 5 MWe micro reactor development
  • DOE HALEU allocation (April 2025)

Strategy: Leverage commercial SMR development for government applications

✅ Radiant's edge: Westinghouse is focused on large terrestrial SMRs (5 MWe eVinci). Radiant built for portability from day one. Different design philosophy.

General Atomics (GA-EMS)
FUEL TECH

Position: Strong NTP fuel technology player.

  • DRACO Track A Phase 1 ($22M, 2021)
  • NASA SNP fuel development contracts (2023, 2025)
  • Successful HALEU fuel testing at NASA Marshall (Jan 2025)

Strategy: Focus on fuel element innovation; position as fuel supplier

✅ Radiant's edge: GA is fuel-focused, not full reactor. Could be supplier to Radiant, not competitor. Different market position.

📋 DoD SBIR/STTR Program

▼

How DoD SBIR Works

  • New topics released first Wednesday monthly
  • Three pre-scheduled BAAs/CSOs per fiscal year
  • Participating components: Army, Navy, Air Force, Space Force, DARPA, MDA, DHA, others
  • Phase I: $50K-275K (feasibility)
  • Phase II: $750K-1.7M (prototype)
  • Phase III: Non-SBIR funds (production)

Portal: defensesbirsttr.mil

Search Keywords

  • nuclear, fission, reactor
  • space power, spacecraft power
  • HALEU, fuel
  • energy conversion, thermal management
  • shielding, radiation
  • autonomous systems, remote operations
  • microreactor, portable power

Cross-Agency Search

SBIR.gov Search all agencies (DoD, NASA, DOE, NSF) in one place. Set alerts for relevant topics.

🤝 Teaming Strategy: How to Partner with Primes

Reactor OEMs rarely win major programs alone. Understanding teaming structures is critical.

The BWXT-Lockheed Model

The DRACO structure is the template: Prime (Lockheed) handles spacecraft design, integration, testing. Reactor OEM (BWXT) provides nuclear subsystem as complete deliverable. DOE provides HALEU; OEM processes into fuel.

Teaming Options for Reactor OEMs

A
Subcontractor to Aerospace Prime
Prime handles government relationships, classified requirements, contract risk. You provide the reactor.

Pros: Lower BD burden, reduced risk, established relationships

Cons: Lower value capture, less program control

Best for: Major programs (FSP, demo missions)

B
Prime with Aerospace Sub
Reactor OEM as prime with spacecraft integration support from partners.

Pros: Maximum value capture, direct government relationship

Cons: Higher BD investment, full contract risk

Best for: Smaller OTA/SBIR, commercial space

C
Joint Venture Structure
Create separate legal entity with complementary partner (like IX = Intuitive Machines + X-Energy).

Pros: Combined capabilities, shared risk, access to partner vehicles

Cons: Complex governance, profit sharing

Best for: Major strategic pursuits

Critical Teaming Agreement Provisions

Must-Have Terms

  • Exclusivity: Mutual for specific opportunities, with duration limits
  • Work Share: Percentage allocation, dollar commitments, scope boundaries
  • Subcontract Certainty: Guarantee of subcontract if prime wins
  • IP Protection: Retain reactor design IP rights
  • Termination: Protection if prime doesn't win

Proposal Responsibilities

  • Technical Volume: Who owns which sections
  • Past Performance: Reference coordination
  • Key Personnel: Named commitments
  • Pricing: Joint strategy development
  • Compliance: FAR/DFARS flow-downs
⚠

Small Business Alert: Ostensible Subcontractor Rule

SBA scrutinizes if small business appears "unusually reliant" on large sub. Must demonstrate small business control and primary work performance. Limit large sub work share (typically <49%). Risk of size protest if structure appears to circumvent requirements.

🎯 Capture Management Framework

Only 55% of government contractors have a formal capture process. Having one significantly boosts win rates.

18-24 Months Out: Opportunity Identification

Find & Qualify Opportunities

  • Monitor SAM.gov, SBIR.gov, agency forecasts
  • Track Sources Sought notices and RFIs
  • Attend industry days and workshops
  • Build opportunity pipeline with PWin estimates
  • Make initial go/no-go decisions
12-18 Months Out: Relationship Building

Develop Customer Intelligence

  • Identify end users, PMs, requirements officers
  • Request capability briefings
  • Submit thoughtful RFI responses
  • Publish relevant white papers
  • Begin teaming discussions
9-12 Months Out: Solution Development

Shape Requirements & Solution

  • Comment on draft RFP language
  • Develop technical solution architecture
  • Finalize teaming agreements
  • Identify win themes and discriminators
  • Conduct competitive analysis
6-9 Months Out: Capture Strategy

Finalize Win Strategy

  • Lock down price-to-win analysis
  • Assign proposal team leads
  • Develop compliance matrix
  • Schedule executive reviews
  • Final go/no-go gate
RFP Release: Proposal Execution

Write & Submit

  • Execute proposal schedule
  • Conduct color team reviews (Pink, Red, Gold)
  • Ensure 100% compliance
  • Submit on time
  • Prepare for orals/demos if required

💰 Budget & Policy Intelligence

Understanding the budget process is essential. Congressional support often exceeds administration requests for space nuclear.

FY2026 Budget Reality

Administration Request (May 2025)

  • NASA cut to $18.8B (from ~$24B)
  • Zeroed out NTP and NEP
  • DRACO cancelled ($0 funding)
  • STMD cut by $531M

Congressional Response

  • NASA: $24.438B (rejected cuts)
  • NTP restored: $110-120M
  • NEP restored: Up to $50M
  • Space Force: $29B ($3B above request)

Strategic Implications

  • Congressional vs. Administration: Congress consistently supports space nuclear at higher levels. Build relationships with appropriators and authorizers.

  • Program Office Matters: NTP/NEP transfer to Mars Campaign Office signals prioritization for human exploration.
  • HALEU is Strategic: DOE commitment to domestic production is enabler. Allocation is competitive advantage.

Force future programs to assume "a Radiant-class reactor" as the baseline.

🌍 The International Race

This is a race. Russia and China are moving faster if we don't.

Russia

  • 32 fission reactors flown (BES-5 "Buk" for ocean surveillance)
  • TOPAZ thermionic reactors (6 months - 1 year operations)
  • Nuclear power station on Moon planned ~2036
  • Partnership with China on ILRS

China

  • International Lunar Research Station (ILRS) includes nuclear power
  • Mid-2030s lunar power timeline
  • Megawatt-class space reactor concepts in development
  • Aggressive investment in nuclear technology
⚠

The Stakes

Whoever establishes nuclear power infrastructure on the Moon first will have strategic advantage for decades. The US has flown only ONE reactor (SNAP-10A, 1965). Russia has flown 32+. China is investing heavily. Speed matters.

🎯 Space BD Lead OKRs: Quarterly Goals Framework

These assume Phase-0 / Phase-1 positioning: shaping missions, winning early studies, and becoming unavoidable before flight programs exist. Use OKRs to focus BD resources on what matters.

The Strategic Logic

Your OKRs drive your white papers. White papers drive RFIs. RFIs become OTAs. OTAs become flight demos. Flight demos become Programs of Record.

By the time an RFP hits SAM.gov, winning vendors have already been shaping the conversation for 12-24 months. These OKRs ensure Radiant is shaping, not chasing.

▼
💡

Why this matters: If you're not in their early concept docs, you don't exist later. Architecture documents become requirements. Requirements become RFPs. Get in early or get locked out.

Key Results

  • Meet with 12+ NASA lunar/surface-power officials
  • Meet with 8+ DoD/Space Force power offices
  • Attend or present at 3+ industry days or workshops
  • Be referenced in 2+ agency concept studies
  • Get invited to at least one closed technical working group
  • Brief NASA Glenn FSP team on Kaleidos capabilities

Target contacts: Steven Sinacore (FSP PE), Lindsay Kaldon (FSP Deputy), Dr. Anthony Calomino (Space Nuclear Portfolio), AFRL Space Vehicles Directorate

▼
💡

Why this matters: Paid paper leads to future hardware. Study contracts build past performance, relationships, and position you for larger awards. Non-dilutive funding funds R&D.

Key Results

  • Submit 6+ RFIs/white papers
  • Submit 3+ SBIR/BAA proposals
  • Win 1+ Phase-I or study award
  • Be named on 2+ prime-led concept submissions
  • Secure 1+ DOE lab partnership letter
  • Track Pwin on all active opportunities

📝 NASA Space-Power White Paper: Complete Writing Guide

When NASA issues an RFI or draft solicitation, they often ask for a 5-10 page concept paper with very specific sections. Here's what agencies actually expect.

💡

Two-Step Process

DARPA and NASA often use a two-step application process: first submit a white paper (3-10 pages), then if selected, you're invited to submit a full proposal. The white paper is your hookmake it count.

📋 Section 1: Executive Summary (1 page)

▼

Clear and sober. No marketing fluff. This is your hookmake every word count.

Example Opening

"Radiant proposes a scalable lunar surface fission power system derived from its mobile terrestrial micro-reactor architecture, optimized for vacuum heat rejection, autonomous operation, and launch-safe subcritical configuration."

Must Include:

  • Mission relevance: What problem does this solve for NASA?
  • Power level: Specific kWe output (e.g., 40-100 kWe for FSP)
  • Why now: What enables this now that wasn't possible before?
  • What NASA gets: Concrete deliverable and value proposition

🛰 Section 2: Mission Applications

▼

Tie directly to NASA/DoD mission needs. Be specific about where your technology fits.

Primary Applications

  • Lunar south-pole bases (Artemis)
  • ISRU plants (oxygen/water extraction)
  • Science outposts (extended operations)
  • Defense dual-use (cislunar awareness)
  • Mars precursors (surface power)

Specify:

  • kW ranges: 40-100 kWe (FSP baseline)
  • Duty cycle: Continuous or variable load
  • Lifetime: 10+ years operation
  • Mass budget: Up to 15 metric tons (FSP)
  • Deployment: Autonomous or human-assisted

⚙ Section 3: Technical Architecture (Core Section)

▼

This is the core of your proposal. No fluff. Engineers read this section first.

Reactor System

  • Reactor type & spectrum: Thermal/fast, moderated/unmoderated
  • Fuel form: HALEU, TRISO, CERMET, other
  • Moderator approach: ZrH, BeO, graphite, none
  • Criticality control: Control drums, rods, reflectors

Thermal & Power

  • Cooling method: Heat pipes, gas loop (He), liquid metal
  • Power conversion: Stirling, Brayton, thermoelectric
  • Radiator concept: Deployable panels, sizing approach
  • Efficiency target: Thermal to electric conversion %

Operations & Safety

  • Shielding: Shadow shield design, materials
  • Autonomy: Startup, load-following, fault response
  • Deployment: Lander integration, surface emplacement

Radiant Differentiators

  • Helium coolant (works in vacuum, non-activating)
  • ZrH moderator (proprietary tech)
  • Autonomous operations DNA
  • Production mindset (not bespoke)

🔐 Section 4: Safety & Launch Approach (Critical)

▼
⚠

This section often decides seriousness. Reviewers look here to see if you understand nuclear safety reality. Weak safety analysis = proposal rejected.

Launch Safety

  • Sub-critical launch state: Reactor cannot go critical during launch or accident
  • Accident scenarios: Launch failure, re-entry, impact
  • Fuel containment: Survives worst-case scenarios
  • Radiological analysis: Dose consequences if containment fails

Regulatory Path

  • NSPM-20: Presidential approval framework
  • Interagency review: NASA, DOE, EPA, NRC
  • NEPA compliance: Environmental review
  • UN treaty compliance: Outer Space Treaty, Liability Convention

📅 Section 5: Development Roadmap

▼

Phased approach with clear milestones. Include dependencies. Be realistic.

Year 1: Modeling & Subscale Tests
  • Detailed neutronics modeling
  • Thermal-hydraulic analysis
  • Component subscale testing
  • Space-variant core design
Year 2: Integrated Ground Prototype
  • Full-scale non-nuclear prototype
  • Thermal vacuum testing
  • Power conversion integration
  • Autonomous control validation
Years 3-4: Space Qualification
  • Nuclear testing at national lab
  • Environmental qualification
  • Safety analysis & approvals
  • Flight unit manufacturing
Year 5+: Flight Demonstration
  • Launch & deployment
  • On-surface/orbit operations
  • Extended mission validation
  • Lessons learned for production

🤝 Section 6: Teaming & Roles

▼

List your team structure. Agencies want to see credible partnerships.

RoleOrganizationResponsibility
Reactor OEMRadiant NuclearCore design, fuel system, autonomy, thermal management
Prime Integrator[Lockheed/Northrop/etc.]Spacecraft integration, mission ops, government interface
National LabINL/ORNL/ANLFuel qualification, testing, safety analysis
Power Conversion[Partner TBD]Stirling or Brayton engine integration
Launch Provider[If applicable]Launch services, mission integration

💰 Section 7: Cost & Schedule ROM

▼

Rough order-of-magnitude. NASA knows these are uncertainjust be credible. Don't lowball.

PhaseDurationCost ROMKey Deliverables
Concept Study12-18 months$5-15MDesign report, trade studies, risk assessment
Preliminary Design18-24 months$15-40MPDR, subscale testing, safety analysis
Ground Demo24-36 months$75-200MFull-scale prototype, nuclear testing
Flight Unit24-36 months$150-400MFlight hardware, qualification, launch

Note: INL white paper recommends fixed-price, milestone-based contracts. Emphasize this approach if aligned with your cost structure.

🏆 Section 8: Why Radiant (Differentiation)

▼

Focused differentiation. Don't list featuresexplain why they matter.

Radiant's Unique Advantages

  • Mobile-reactor heritage: Kaleidos designed for transportabilitytranslates to launch mass constraints
  • Moderator IP: Proprietary ZrH technology, proven physics
  • Autonomy DNA: No astronaut maintenance; self-start, self-regulate, self-protect
  • Production mindset: Built for manufacturing, not bespokeexactly what DARPA wants
  • Licensing experience: DOE relationships, NRC pathway understanding
  • Capital & speed: $300M+ raised, startup velocity vs. incumbent pace

The Winning Statement

"We've already built and tested hardware, secured HALEU, won a military contract, and are partnered with DOE national labs. We're not a PowerPoint company."

  • DIU/USAF contract in hand
  • DOE HALEU allocation secured

🤖 DARPA Proposal Tips: What Makes You Stand Out

DARPA evaluates differently than NASA. They want revolutionary, not incremental. Here's how to position for DARPA success.

What DARPA Wants to See

  • Technical novelty plus realism: Revolutionary but achievable
  • Defense payoff: How does this give warfighters an edge?
  • "Why now": What enables this that wasn't possible before?
  • Clear milestones: How will you prove it works?
  • Team credibility: Named PIs with relevant expertise
  • Producibility: Can this scale beyond a demo?

Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • Incremental improvements: DARPA funds leaps, not steps
  • Vague milestones: "Research will be conducted" = rejected
  • Ignoring competitors: Show you know the landscape
  • Missing safety analysis: Especially for nuclear
  • Inconsistent documents: SOW must match proposal
  • Lowball costs: Unrealistic budgets flag inexperience

🌟 Why Nuclear Power for Space?

Nuclear isn't always the answerbut for certain missions, it's the only answer.

The Fundamental Problem

Solar power works well in the inner solar system during daylight. But what happens during 14-day lunar nights? Month-long Mars dust storms? Missions to Jupiter where solar flux is 4% of Earth levels? Nuclear provides continuous, reliable power regardless of sunlight.

Solar vs Nuclear: When Each Wins

FactorSolarNuclear FissionRTGs
Specific Power~30 W/kg typical~6-7 W/kg~5-8 W/kg
Lunar Night (14 days)✖ Requires massive batteries✔ Continuous power✔ Continuous power
Mars Dust Storms✖ Up to 95% blocked✔ Unaffected✔ Unaffected
Jupiter Distance✖ Only 4% flux✔ Distance irrelevant✔ Distance irrelevant
High Power (>50 kW)Massive arrays needed✔ Ideal range✖ Pu-238 limited
10+ Year LifeDegradation issues✔ Designed for it✔ Voyager: 47+ years

The Lunar Night Problem

  • Lunar day-night cycle: 29.5 Earth days
  • 14 consecutive days of complete darkness
  • Temperatures drop to -173C (-280F)
  • Battery storage for 14 days is far beyond current tech
  • Solar landers go dormant and may not survive

The Mars Dust Problem

  • Global dust storms last weeks to months
  • Block up to 95% of sunlight
  • 2018 storm killed Opportunity rover
  • Curiosity (nuclear) was unaffected
  • Mars gets only 43% of Earth's solar irradiance anyway

📚 Understanding Nuclear Fission: A Complete Guide

From the basics to Radiant's micro-reactor. Start here if you're new to nuclear technology.

Part 1: What Is Nuclear Fission?

Imagine breaking a heavy rock in two, and discovering that the two pieces weigh slightly less than the original rock. That tiny bit of "missing" matter has been converted into an enormous amount of energy. That's nuclear fission.

⚙ The Fission Process Visualized

       NEUTRON                    URANIUM-235 ATOM
          ●  →→→→→                   ⬤
         (n)                    (92 protons
                                143 neutrons)

                    ⬇ COLLISION ⬇

           💥💥💥 ATOM SPLITS 💥💥💥

      ●                              ●
       ↖    FISSION FRAGMENT      ↗
          ⬤  (e.g., Barium)  ⬤
           ↘                  ↙
              ●   +   ●   +   ●
            (2-3 NEW NEUTRONS)
                    +
           🔥 ENERGY (HEAT) 🔥

Each fission releases ~200 million electron volts of energy and 2-3 new neutrons that can split more atoms.

💡 The Key Insight

When uranium-235 absorbs a neutron, its nucleus becomes so unstable that it splits into two smaller atoms. During this split, a tiny amount of mass is converted directly into energy according to Einstein's famous equation:

E = mc²

Because the speed of light (c) is so enormous (300 million m/s), even a tiny amount of mass converts to a huge amount of energy.

⚡ Why It's So Powerful

A single kilogram of uranium-235, fully fissioned, releases the same energy as:

  • 3 million kg of coal
  • 2.7 million liters of gasoline
  • 20 billion calories of food

That's 2-3 million times more energy per kg than chemical fuels!

🔄 The Chain Reaction: How Power Is Sustained

The magic of nuclear power lies in the chain reaction. Each fission event releases 2-3 new neutrons. If one of those neutrons hits another uranium atom and causes it to split, the reaction sustains itself.

⚡ Chain Reaction Visualization

Generation 1:              ●→⬤💥
                              ↓
Generation 2:         ●→⬤💥   ●→⬤💥
                         ↓           ↓
Generation 3:    ●→⬤💥 ●→⬤💥 ●→⬤💥 ●→⬤💥
                    ↓      ↓      ↓      ↓
                   (8 fissions in generation 4...)

● = neutron   ⬤ = uranium atom   💥 = fission event

In just 80 generations (a fraction of a second), a single neutron can trigger 1024 fission events!

✔ Controlled Chain Reaction (Reactor)

On average, exactly 1 neutron from each fission goes on to cause another fission. The reaction sustains itself at a steady rate. Extra neutrons are absorbed by control materials.

Result: Steady heat production for years

✖ Uncontrolled Chain Reaction (Bomb)

Multiple neutrons from each fission cause more fissions. The reaction multiplies exponentially in microseconds. Requires highly enriched uranium (>90%) in a specific geometry.

This is physically impossible in reactor fuel (<20% enrichment)

Part 2: How Micro-Reactors Work

A micro-reactor is simply a very small nuclear reactor. Think of it as shrinking a power plant down to shipping-container size. The physics are the same; the engineering is different.

🔧 The Five Essential Components

Every fission reactor, from giant power plants to portable micro-reactors, needs the same five components:

████████████████████████████████████████
█  ▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒  █
█  ▒  ┌────────────────────────┐  ▒  █  ◀ SHIELDING (5)
█  ▒  │  ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤  │  ▒  █
█  ▒  │  ⬤[FUEL]⬤[FUEL]⬤  │  ▒  █  ◀ FUEL (1)
█  ▒  │  ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤  │  ▒  █
█  ▒  │      [MODERATOR]      │  ▒  █  ◀ MODERATOR (2)
█  ▒  │  ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤ ⬤  │  ▒  █
█  ▒  └────────────────────────┘  ▒  █
█  ▒           ↑↑↑               ▒  █
█  ▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒[COOLANT]▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒  █  ◀ COOLANT (3)
████████████████████████████████████████
          ▼                   ▼
    [CONTROL]             [CONTROL]              ◀ CONTROL SYSTEM (4)

1. Fuel ⚡

The uranium (or other fissile material) that undergoes fission. For micro-reactors, this is typically HALEU (High-Assay Low-Enriched Uranium) at 5-20% U-235 enrichment. Higher enrichment = smaller core.

2. Moderator 🔄

Material that slows down neutrons. Fast neutrons from fission are less likely to cause more fissions. Slow "thermal" neutrons are ~1000x more effective. Common moderators: water, graphite, zirconium hydride.

3. Coolant 🌡

Carries heat away from the reactor core to be converted to electricity. Can be water, gas (helium), liquid metal, or molten salt. Micro-reactors often use helium or heat pipes for simplicity and safety.

4. Control System 🔧

Regulates the chain reaction by absorbing neutrons. More neutrons absorbed = less fissions = less power. Control rods, drums, or blades containing boron or similar materials are inserted/rotated to adjust power.

5. Shielding 🛡

Protects people and equipment from radiation. Fission produces neutrons and gamma rays that must be contained. Lead, concrete, and water are common shielding materials. Micro-reactors use "shadow shielding" - only shielding in the direction of people.

🧰 What Makes Micro-Reactors Different?

FeatureTraditional ReactorMicro-Reactor
Power Output500-1,400 MWe1-20 MWe
SizeBuilding-sizedShipping container
ConstructionBuilt on-site (years)Factory-built, deployed
OperatorsHundreds of staffAutonomous or minimal
RefuelingEvery 18-24 monthsEvery 5-10+ years (or swap unit)
CoolingRequires water sourceAir-cooled or heat pipes
Enrichment3-5% (LEU)5-20% (HALEU)

📈 How Power Is Regulated

Controlling a reactor is all about controlling neutrons. More neutrons = more fissions = more power.

▼▼▼ INSERT CONTROL MATERIAL ▼▼▼     ▲▲▲ WITHDRAW CONTROL MATERIAL ▲▲▲

    Neutrons     →    ABSORBED           Neutrons    →    REFLECTED BACK
        ● ● ●          ✖                  ● ● ●          🔄 → ⬤💥

    Fewer fissions                       More fissions
    Less heat                            More heat

    🔵 POWER DECREASES                   🟢 POWER INCREASES

Neutron absorbers (boron, cadmium) capture neutrons. Reflectors (graphite, beryllium) bounce them back into the core.

⚡ How Radiant's Kaleidos Micro-Reactor Works

A deep dive into Radiant's proprietary technology - the Kaleidos portable nuclear generator.

The Big Picture

Kaleidos is a high-temperature gas-cooled reactor (HTGR) that fits in a shipping container. It uses TRISO fuel (the safest fuel type), helium gas coolant (which can't become radioactive), and zirconium hydride moderator (Radiant's innovation for compact design).

1 MWe
Electric Output
3 MWt
Thermal Output
5 years
Fuel Cycle
20 years
Service Life

🔥 The Fuel Journey: From Rock to Reactor

Uranium Enrichment to HALEU to TRISO

⛧ NATURAL URANIUM    →    ENRICHMENT    →    HALEU    →    TRISO FUEL
   (0.7% U-235)            (centrifuge)        (19.75%)        (ceramic-coated
                                                                particles)

● TRISO Particle Cross-Section:

           ◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎
          ◎                     ◎
         ◎   ███████████     ◎   ◀ Outer Carbon Layer
        ◎   █ ▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒ █    ◎   ◀ Silicon Carbide (SiC)
       ◎   █ ▒ ░░░░░░░ ▒ █   ◎   ◀ Inner Carbon Layer
       ◎   █ ▒ ░ ▄▄▄ ░ ▒ █   ◎   ◀ Buffer Carbon
       ◎   █ ▒ ░ ▄●▄ ░ ▒ █   ◎   ◀ UCO KERNEL (fuel)

        ◎   █ ▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒▒ █    ◎   ~1mm diameter
         ◎   ███████████     ◎   (poppy seed size)
          ◎                     ◎
           ◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎◎

🛡 Why TRISO Is "Meltdown-Proof"

  • Each particle is its own tiny containment vessel
  • Silicon carbide layer survives 1,650C for 300+ hours
  • Even if all cooling fails, fuel stays intact
  • Traditional fuel fails at ~1,200C; TRISO keeps going
  • DOE calls it "the most robust nuclear fuel on Earth"

💡 Key Difference from Traditional Fuel

Traditional reactors use fuel rods with pellets. If a rod breaches, radioactive gases escape. TRISO encapsulates each fuel particle individually - a breach in one particle affects nothing else. It's like having millions of tiny containment vessels instead of one big one.

☢ How Neutrons Flow in the Kaleidos Core

┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│             GRAPHITE REFLECTOR RING                  │
│   ┌───┐┌───┐                          ┌───┐┌───┐   │
│   │B4C││   │←← ROTATING CONTROL DRUMS →→│   ││B4C│   │
│   └───┘└───┘      (Boron Carbide)       └───┘└───┘   │
│          ┌──────────────────────┐          │
│   ↑      │     REACTOR CORE        │      ↑   │
│ neutron  │  ●→⬤💥→●●→⬤💥→●  │ neutron  │
│  bounce  │  ↓            ↓       │  bounce  │
│   ↓      │  ⬤💥←●●←⬤💥←●  │   ↓      │
│          │  [TRISO][ZrH2][TRISO]  │          │
│   GRAPHITE │  FUEL  MOD   FUEL    │ GRAPHITE  │
│  REFLECTS  └──────────────────────┘ REFLECTS  │
│  NEUTRONS                            NEUTRONS  │
│   BACK     ↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑↑     BACK     │
│          [HELIUM COOLANT FLOWS UP]             │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

● = neutron   ⬤ = fuel atom   💥 = fission   ZrH2 = moderator

⚇ Graphite Reflector

A ring of graphite surrounds the core. When neutrons try to escape, the graphite bounces them back into the fuel. This improves fuel efficiency - fewer neutrons are wasted, more cause fissions.

🔄 Rotating Control Drums

Instead of control rods, Kaleidos uses rotating drums with boron carbide (B4C) on one side. Rotate drums toward core = boron absorbs neutrons = power down. Rotate away = graphite reflects = power up.

🔬 Radiant's Zirconium Hydride Innovation

Why ZrH₂ Matters

Zirconium hydride is packed with hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen is the best neutron moderator because it's similar in mass to a neutron - like a cue ball hitting another cue ball, it transfers energy efficiently.

  • Enables a much more compact core
  • Slows neutrons in less space
  • Works at high temperatures
  • Key to fitting a reactor in a shipping container

How It's Used

The ZrH₂ is encapsulated in the core structure. Helium coolant flows through channels directly cooling the moderator. This:

  • Limits peak temperatures in the moderator
  • Reduces thermal gradients
  • Prevents hydrogen migration
  • Enables stable, predictable performance

🌡 The Helium Coolant System

Heat Flow Diagram

┌─────────┐      ┌───────────────┐      ┌───────────────┐      ┌─────────┐
│  REACTOR │      │     HEAT      │      │   BRAYTON     │      │ ELECTRIC │
│   CORE   │ →→→ │   EXCHANGER   │ →→→ │   TURBINE     │ →→→ │ GENERATOR│
│  (HEAT)  │      │              │      │   (sCO2)      │      │          │
└─────────┘      └───────────────┘      └───────────────┘      └─────────┘
     ↑                   ↑
     │                   │
 HOT HELIUM →→→→→→→→→→→→┬
     ↑                   │
     │              TRANSFERS HEAT
     │              TO sCO2 LOOP
 COOL HELIUM ←←←←←←←←←←←┴
     ↑                   ↓
     │                   │
┌────┴─────┐    ┌─────┴─────────┐
│  HELIUM   │    │    WASTE       │
│ COMPRESSOR│    │  HEAT TO AIR  │
│ (THE PUMP)│    │  (RADIATOR)   │
└──────────┘    └───────────────┘

✔ Why Helium Is Ideal

  • Cannot become radioactive - helium is the only element that doesn't activate under neutron bombardment because it's already atomically stable
  • Chemically inert - won't corrode anything
  • Works at very high temperatures
  • No phase changes (stays gas)
  • Simplifies safety case dramatically

⚙ The Heart of the System

The helium compressor is the main moving part. It:

  • Pushes helium through the reactor core
  • Extracts hot helium carrying heat
  • Brings it to the heat exchanger
  • Uses magnetic bearings (no contact = long life)

🛡 Passive Safety Features

Kaleidos is designed so that even with complete failure of all active systems, the reactor safely shuts down on its own.

⏳ 300 Millisecond Auto-Shutdown

If power is lost or any control problem is detected, the reactor automatically shuts down within 300 milliseconds (faster than you can blink). No operator action required.

🌡 Natural Air Cooling

The reactor is small enough that after shutdown, natural air convection is sufficient to remove decay heat. No pumps, no water, no electricity needed for emergency cooling.

🔥 Negative Temperature Coefficient

Physics works in your favor: as the reactor heats up, the chain reaction naturally slows down. This is built into the fuel and moderator behavior. Runaway reactions are physically impossible.

🔒 TRISO Containment

Even under extreme conditions, TRISO fuel retains all radioactive fission products. There's no scenario where the public could be exposed to dangerous radiation levels.

💻 Digital Twin Technology

Radiant developed SimEngine, proprietary software that creates a real-time digital twin of the Kaleidos reactor. This allows:

  • Simulation of startup, shutdown, and off-normal scenarios
  • Calculation of temperatures throughout the core
  • Rapid design iterations (test changes virtually before building)
  • Coupled physics simulations (neutronics + thermal + fluid)
  • Validation against real test data
  • Hardware control system development

Result: Faster development cycles and higher confidence in safety before any fuel is ever loaded.
