☢ Nuclear Fission: How It Works

Understanding fission physics is essential for evaluating reactor designs and talking to technical stakeholders.

The Fission Process

  1. A neutron strikes a uranium-235 atom
  2. The U-235 nucleus absorbs the neutron and becomes unstable
  3. The nucleus splits into two lighter "fission fragments"
  4. Energy is released (~200 MeV per fission)
  5. 2-3 new neutrons are released
  6. Those neutrons can cause more fissions chain reaction

Key fact: Fission releases ~2 million times more energy per kg than burning coal.

Criticality States

Statek ValueMeaning
Subcriticalk < 1Chain reaction dies out
Criticalk = 1Self-sustaining (normal operation)
Supercriticalk > 1Power increasing

k = multiplication factor (neutrons produced / neutrons lost). Reactors are designed to maintain k 1 during operation.

Neutron Moderation: Why It Matters

Neutrons from fission are "fast" (~20,000 km/s). But U-235 fissions hundreds of times more efficiently with "slow" (thermal) neutrons. Moderators slow neutrons down through collisions.

HO
Light Water - Most common moderator
C
Graphite - Solid moderator
ZrH
Zirconium Hydride - Radiant's innovation
Be
Beryllium - Excellent but expensive

Power Control Mechanisms

Control Rods

Neutron-absorbing materials (boron, cadmium, hafnium) inserted/withdrawn to control neutron population. Insert rods absorb neutrons reduce power. Withdraw increase power.

Inherent Feedback

Negative temperature coefficient: As fuel heats up, fission rate naturally decreases. This is a critical safety featurerunaway reactions are physically impossible in well-designed reactors.

⚡ HALEU Fuel: The Enabler of Space Nuclear

HALEU (High-Assay Low-Enriched Uranium) is the key fuel that makes compact space reactors possible.

Uranium Enrichment Levels

CategoryU-235 ContentPrimary Uses
Natural Uranium0.7%CANDU reactors (with heavy water)
Standard LEU3-5%Commercial power reactors
HALEU5-20%Advanced reactors, SMRs, space reactors
HEU20%+Research reactors, naval propulsion
Weapons-grade>90%Nuclear weapons
💡

Why 20% Matters

The 20% boundary is internationally significant: the IAEA considers LEU (<20%) "indirect material" that cannot be directly used for weapons, while HEU (20%) is "direct use material." HALEU stays just below this threshold while enabling compact cores.

Why HALEU Enables Compact Space Reactors

  • Smaller core size: Higher U-235 concentration = same power from smaller fuel volume
  • Better neutron economy: More neutrons available to sustain chain reaction
  • Longer operating life: Higher burnup possible = longer missions without refueling
  • Reduced moderator needs: Higher enrichment may allow simpler, lighter designs
  • Mass is existential in space: Every kg saved is $5K-50K in launch costs
  • Only ~9% more mass than HEU cores with far easier regulatory approval

HALEU Supply Chain (Critical Challenge)

The Problem

  • Only Russia and China have commercial-scale HALEU production
  • Russia controls ~44% of global enrichment capacity
  • US imports from Russia being phased out (ban by 2028)
  • DOE estimates US needs 50 metric tons/year by 2035

US Producers Building Capacity

  • Centrus Energy (Piketon, OH) - First US HALEU in 70 years (2023). $900M DOE contract.
  • Orano (Oak Ridge, TN) - $900M contract, production early 2030s
  • Urenco USA (Eunice, NM) - HALEU expansion planned
  • Radiant has DOE HALEU allocation (April 2025) ✔

🔥 Fuel Forms for Space Reactors

Different missions require different fuel technologies. Each has trade-offs in safety, performance, and manufacturability.

TRISO Fuel The "Meltdown-Proof" Fuel

▼

TRISO (TRi-structural ISOtropic) particles are poppy-seed-sized fuel kernels with multiple protective ceramic layers. Each particle is its own containment system.

Five-Layer Structure

  1. Kernel: UCO or UO fuel (350-500 m)
  2. Buffer: Porous carbon - absorbs fission recoils
  3. Inner PyC: Dense carbon - protects SiC layer
  4. Silicon Carbide: Primary barrier - the "pressure vessel"
  5. Outer PyC: Dense carbon - structural support

Why TRISO Is Safe

  • Cannot melt: Survives >1,650C for 300+ hours
  • Each particle is its own containment
  • Retains fission products under all conditions
  • Tested to 2,500K for nuclear thermal propulsion
  • Called "the most robust nuclear fuel on Earth" by DOE

CERMET Fuel Extreme Temperature Performance

▼

CERMET (CERamic METal) fuel embeds ceramic fuel particles in a refractory metal matrix. Ideal for nuclear thermal propulsion where temperatures exceed 2,500K.

Structure

  • Ceramic phase: UO or UN particles
  • Metal matrix: Tungsten or molybdenum
  • Geometry: Hexagonal elements with coolant channels

Advantages

  • Operates at >2,500K in hydrogen
  • Survives thermal cycling
  • High thermal conductivity
  • 10+ year missions possible

Uranium Nitride (UN) NASA's Preferred Space Fuel

▼

Uranium nitride offers the best balance of thermal conductivity and uranium density for space applications.

PropertyUNUO (oxide)Advantage
Thermal Conductivity23 W/m-K2.3 W/m-K10x higher
Uranium Density13.51 g/cm9.66 g/cm40% higher
Melting Point2,630C2,847CBoth very high

Used in SP-100 design, Kilopower concepts, and NASA nuclear thermal propulsion studies.

Radiant's Approach: Zirconium Hydride Moderator + Helium Coolant

▼

Zirconium Hydride Moderator

  • Proprietary moderator technology
  • Hydrogen-rich = excellent neutron moderation
  • Enables compact core designs
  • Packs fission physics into shipping-container scale

Helium Gas Coolant

  • Cannot become radioactive in the reactor
  • Works in vacuum (no fluid management issues)
  • No activation concerns
  • Simplifies safety case significantly
  • Ideal for space applications

💫 Power Conversion Technologies

Converting reactor heat to electricity. The choice depends on power level, reliability requirements, and mission duration.

S
Stirling Engines

Efficiency: 20-40%

  • Free-piston design minimizes wear
  • Best for <50 kWe systems
  • Lowest mass option
  • Multiple engines = redundancy

Con: Moving parts

B
Brayton Turbines

Efficiency: 20-33%

  • Closed cycle with He or He-Xe
  • Ideal for megawatt-scale
  • Fast dynamic response
  • Compact structure

Con: Complex turbomachinery

T
Thermoelectrics

Efficiency: 5-8%

  • No moving parts
  • Highest reliability
  • Decades of space heritage
  • Simple, robust construction

Con: Very low efficiency

💡

The Trade-Off

Dynamic systems (Stirling, Brayton) achieve efficiencies up to 6x greater than thermoelectrics (~30% vs ~5%). But thermoelectrics have proven 47+ year reliability (Voyager). Mission requirements dictate the choice.

🌡 Heat Rejection in Space

In vacuum, only radiation works. No air, no water, no convection. This drives some of the most challenging engineering in space nuclear systems.

The Stefan-Boltzmann Law

Q = AT

Radiated power scales with the fourth power of temperature. Double the temperature 16x the radiated power. This strongly incentivizes high-temperature radiators.

Heat Pipe Systems

Baseline technology for space heat rejection. Completely passive with no moving parts.

TemperatureWorking Fluid
<500 KWater
600-800 KPotassium
900-1100 KSodium
1100-1400 KLithium

Radiator Mass Challenge

For a 100 kWe reactor with ~10% efficiency, ~1 MW of thermal power must be dissipated. This requires:

  • ~50 m radiator area
  • ~500 kg radiator mass
  • Radiators are often the largest component by volume

Advanced materials: Carbon-carbon composites, titanium headers, achieving 3-4 kg/m.

🛡 Radiation Shielding

You can't encase a space reactor in concrete. Shielding must be mass-optimized while protecting crew and electronics.

Shielding Materials

For Neutrons:

  • Lithium Hydride (LiH) Best mass-optimized neutron absorber
  • Borated polymers, BC

For Gamma Rays:

  • Tungsten Primary gamma shield (20+ cm typical)
  • Depleted uranium, lead

Shadow Shielding Concept

For unmanned missions, only shield the direction toward payload/crew. Truncated cone shape creates a "shadow" that protects electronics.

Typical config: 20 cm tungsten + 40 cm LiH

Shield mass fraction: 17-43% of total system mass

Distance as Shielding (Inverse Square Law)

Radiation intensity follows I 1/r. At 2x distance 1/4 exposure. At 10x distance 1/100 exposure. Extended booms of 10-50 meters are common to position reactors away from payload.

🤖 Autonomy & Reliability Requirements

No operators. No spare parts. No quick repairs. Space reactors must run untouched for a decade or more.

10+
Years without maintenance
0
Operators available
0
Spare parts available
47+
Years (Voyager RTGs still running)

Autonomous Requirements

  • Self-start after reaching destination
  • Self-regulate power output
  • Load-following (adjust to demand changes)
  • Fault detection and diagnosis
  • Autonomous SCRAM (emergency shutdown)
  • Reconfigure loads automatically
  • Survive with failed components (redundancy)
  • Communicate status to Earth
✅

KRUSTY Validation

"We threw everything we could at this reactor, in terms of nominal and off-normal operating scenarios, and KRUSTY passed with flying colors." NASA, after Kilopower ground testing validated autonomous operation.

🚀 Launch Safety & Regulatory Framework

Launch approval is often the longest pole in the tent. The regulatory framework exists to ensure nuclear materials are safe even in worst-case accidents.

Core Safety Principle

Reactors launch cold and subcritical with essentially no radioactive inventory. Startup only occurs after reaching orbit/destination. This eliminates fission product hazards during launch accidents.

Design Requirements

  • Remain subcritical in all accident scenarios
  • Survive water/seawater immersion subcritical
  • Withstand launch vibration and abort
  • Survive reentry intact (modern approach)

NSPM-20 Framework (2019)

Presidential memorandum establishing the current launch authorization process:

  • Interagency Nuclear Safety Review Board (INSRB) Standing review body
  • Members: State, DOD, DOE, DOT, EPA, NASA, NRC
  • Tiered approach based on risk level
  • Lower-risk launches: agency-level approval
  • Higher-risk missions: interagency review Presidential decision
⚠

Lesson from SNAP-9A (1964)

Transit satellite with RTG failed to reach orbit and disintegrated on reentry, dispersing ~1 kg of Pu-238 globally. Led to major changes: modern designs are built to survive reentry intact rather than "burn up and disperse."

🌑 Space Nuclear Use Cases

Cislunar & Lunar Surface

Lunar Base Power (Artemis)
40-100 kWe
  • Survive 14-day lunar nights
  • Support crew habitats, life support
  • NASA FSP targeting 100 kWe by 2030
  • Up to 15 metric tons total system mass
Lunar ISRU Operations
30-250 kWe
  • Extract water from permanently shadowed craters
  • Electrolyze water oxygen + hydrogen
  • Extract oxygen from regolith (42-45% by weight)
  • Power-intensive: megawatts for large-scale

Military & Defense Applications

Space-Based Radar & ISR
10-200 kWe
  • Soviet RORSAT flew 33 nuclear reactors for radar
  • All-weather, day/night imaging
  • High-power eliminates large solar array vulnerability
  • Reduces target signature
Nuclear Electric Propulsion (NEP)
100 kWe - 1 MWe
  • "Maneuver without regret" no energy constraints
  • High efficiency (Isp 1,500-10,000+ seconds)
  • Ideal for station-keeping, orbit transfers
  • SPAR Institute: $35M Space Force investment

Mars & Deep Space

Mars Surface Habitat
40 kWe
  • Unaffected by dust storms
  • NASA baseline: 4-5 Kilopower units + spare
  • Supports life support, science, communications
  • Placed distant from habitat (radiation shielding via berm)
Mars ISRU Propellant Production
30-250 kWe
  • Sabatier reaction: CO + H CH + O
  • Produce methane/oxygen rocket propellant
  • 12-15 month production phases
  • Large-scale: 240 kWe (six 40 kWe units)

Technology Selection Rule of Thumb

  • <1 kW: RTGs (proven, no moving parts)
  • 1-10 kW: Kilopower-class fission
  • 10-100 kW: Fission Surface Power designs
  • 100 kW - 1 MW: Advanced fission (Brayton/Stirling)
  • >1 MW: Megawatt-class fission (future development)

📅 Space Nuclear Timeline: 1954-Present

1954

Project Feedback

RAND Corporation study identifies need for space-based nuclear power for reconnaissance satellites.

1955

SNAP Program Begins

Joint USAF-AEC committee launches "Pied Piper" program, later renamed Systems for Nuclear Auxiliary Power (SNAP).

1959

First SNAP Reactor Critical

SNAP Experimental Reactor (SER) achieves criticality at Santa Susana Field Laboratory.

1961

First RTG in Space

Transit 4A launches with SNAP-3B RTG - first nuclear power source in orbit (2.7 watts).

1964

SNAP-9A Accident

Transit 5BN-3 fails to reach orbit, disperses 1 kg of Pu-238 globally. Drives design changes.

1965

SNAP-10A: First Reactor in Space

USA launches world's first fission reactor into orbit. Operates for 43 days before electrical failure.

1967

Soviet RORSAT Program Begins

USSR launches first BES-5 "Buk" reactor for ocean surveillance. Will eventually fly 31 reactors.

1969-1972

Apollo RTGs

Apollo 12, 14, 15, 16, 17 deploy SNAP-27 RTGs on the Moon for ALSEP science stations.

1977

Voyager 1 & 2 Launch

Twin spacecraft with MHW-RTGs begin their grand tour. Still operating 47+ years later.

1978

Kosmos 954 Crash

Soviet reactor satellite crashes in Canada, scatters debris over 124,000 km. Shapes international policy.

1983

SP-100 Program Starts

Triagency (NASA/DOD/DOE) 100 kWe reactor program begins. Cancelled 1994 after $400M spent.

1987

TOPAZ Reactors Fly

USSR launches advanced thermionic reactors on Kosmos 1818 and 1867 (6 kWe each).

1997

Cassini Launches

Most powerful RTG mission: 3 RTGs, 870W, 33 kg Pu-238. Operates at Saturn for 13 years.

2005

Project Prometheus Cancelled

Ambitious JIMO mission (200 kWe reactor to Jupiter's moons) cancelled after $464M invested.

2012

Curiosity Lands on Mars

First MMRTG powers a Mars rover. Still operating 12+ years later.

2018

KRUSTY Test Success

First US fission reactor test in 50+ years. Proves Kilopower concept works. Game-changer.

2020

Perseverance Lands

Second MMRTG rover on Mars. Nuclear power enables sample caching mission.

2022

NASA FSP Phase 1

NASA awards contracts for 40 kWe lunar fission system concepts to Lockheed, Westinghouse, IX.

2025

China-Russia Nuclear Deal

China and Russia sign agreement to deploy nuclear reactor on Moon by 2035 for ILRS.

☢ Two Types of Space Nuclear Power

Understanding the difference between RTGs and fission reactors is fundamental to space nuclear history.

🔥 RTGs (Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators)

Decay Heat Electricity

  • Fuel: Plutonium-238 (not fissile, just hot)
  • Power: Hundreds of watts (not kilowatts)
  • Lifespan: Decades (Pu-238 half-life: 87.7 years)
  • Control: None needed - always on
  • Moving parts: Zero
  • Heritage: 45+ RTGs flown since 1961

Best for: Deep space probes, rovers, long-duration low-power missions

⚛ Fission Reactors

Chain Reaction Electricity

  • Fuel: Enriched uranium (U-235)
  • Power: Kilowatts to megawatts
  • Lifespan: Years (fuel-dependent)
  • Control: Active control required
  • Moving parts: Depends on design
  • Heritage: 1 US, 33 Soviet flown

Best for: Surface bases, high-power spacecraft, ISRU, propulsion

The Power Gap

RTGs top out around 300-500 watts. Fission reactors start at kilowatts and scale to megawatts. There's a critical "middle gap" (500W to 10kW) that neither technology served well - until Kilopower/KRUSTY filled it.

🇺🇸 The SNAP Program (1955-1973)

Systems for Nuclear Auxiliary Power - America's first comprehensive space nuclear program.

Program Structure

Odd numbers = RTGs (SNAP-3, SNAP-9, SNAP-19, SNAP-27)

Even numbers = Reactors (SNAP-2, SNAP-8, SNAP-10A)

Key SNAP RTG Missions

SystemMissionDatePowerOutcome
SNAP-3BTransit 4AJun 19612.7 WFirst RTG in space - 15 year operation
SNAP-9ATransit 5BN-1/2196325 WSuccessful navigation satellites
SNAP-9ATransit 5BN-3Apr 196425 WLaunch failure - Pu-238 dispersed globally
SNAP-19Nimbus 3Apr 196930 WFirst RTG on weather satellite
SNAP-19Pioneer 10/111972-73155 WFirst to Jupiter, Saturn - 30+ years
SNAP-27Apollo 12-171969-7270 WPowered lunar science stations for years

On April 3, 1965, the United States launched the world's first nuclear fission reactor into orbit. It remains the only American reactor ever flown in space.

Technical Specifications

  • Thermal Power: 40 kW
  • Electric Power: 500-650 watts
  • Fuel: Uranium-zirconium hydride
  • Coolant: NaK (sodium-potassium)
  • Conversion: Thermoelectric (SiGe)
  • Mass: 435 kg
  • Orbit: 1,300 km altitude

Mission Results

  • Launch: Vandenberg AFB, Apr 3, 1965
  • Startup: Activated in orbit via ground command
  • Operation: 43 days of power generation
  • Shutdown: Spacecraft voltage regulator failure
  • Status: Still in orbit today
  • Expected reentry: ~4,000 years
✔

Verdict: Technical Success

The reactor itself worked perfectly. It was started remotely, produced steady power, and maintained stable operation. The failure was in the spacecraft's electrical system, not the reactor. SNAP-10A proved space fission power was achievable.

On April 21, 1964, a navigation satellite carrying a SNAP-9A RTG failed to reach orbit and burned up over the Indian Ocean.

What Happened

  • Transit 5BN-3 satellite launched from Vandenberg AFB
  • Launch vehicle failed; satellite reentered atmosphere
  • RTG burned up at ~45 km altitude over southern hemisphere
  • ~1 kg (17,000 Curies) of Pu-238 dispersed globally
  • Traces detected worldwide by 1970 soil sampling

Health Impact

Calculations showed average exposure of 0.04 micro-rem per person globally - far below any health threshold. No health effects attributed to this incident.

Design Changes Implemented

  • Intact reentry requirement: All future RTGs must survive reentry without releasing fuel
  • Fuel encapsulation: Pu-238 now in ceramic form (PuO) in iridium capsules
  • Multi-layer containment: Graphite impact shells (GPHS modules)
  • Launch safety analysis: Comprehensive risk assessment required

🇷🇺 Soviet/Russian Space Reactors (1967-1988)

While the US flew one reactor, the USSR flew 33 nuclear-powered satellites. This is the real operational heritage of space fission.

33
Nuclear Satellites Launched
31
BES-5 Buk Reactors
2
TOPAZ Reactors
21 yrs
Program Duration

The US-A program (RORSAT in the West) used nuclear power to track NATO naval vessels using side-looking radar. The power demands of active radar required nuclear reactors.

BES-5 "Buk" Reactor Specifications

Thermal Power100 kW
Electric Power3 kW
Fuel90% enriched U-235
CoolantNaK-78 (78% potassium, 22% sodium)
ConversionThermoelectric
Design Life1,080 hours (~45 days)
Actual Lifetimes44-131 days

Operational Concept

  • Low Earth orbit (~260 km) required for radar performance
  • Nuclear power essential - solar panels would create too much drag
  • At end of mission, reactor core boosted to ~950 km "disposal orbit"
  • Disposal orbit provides 300-600 year decay time
  • NaK coolant droplets still in orbit - space debris concern

TOPAZ represented a major leap - using thermionic conversion (direct electron emission) instead of thermoelectrics for 2x higher efficiency.

TOPAZ-I Specifications

  • Electric Power: 5-6 kW
  • Efficiency: ~5% (vs 2% for BES-5)
  • Mass: ~1,000 kg
  • Fuel: Highly enriched uranium
  • Moderator: Zirconium hydride
  • Coolant: NaK
  • Design Life: 1 year
  • Conversion: Thermionic diodes

Flight History

  • Kosmos 1818 (Feb 1987): Operated ~6 months
  • Kosmos 1867 (Jul 1987): Operated ~1 year (achieved design life)
💡

US-Russian Cooperation

In 1991, after the Cold War ended, the US purchased two TOPAZ-II reactors from Russia for $13 million. They were tested at Sandia National Laboratory, providing valuable data for American space reactor development.

The most significant space nuclear accident in history - and the event that shaped international policy on space reactors.

What Happened

  • Sep 18, 1977: Kosmos 954 launched with BES-5 reactor (50 kg U-235)
  • Late 1977: Satellite develops control problems
  • Jan 6, 1978: Malfunction prevents reactor core separation for boost to disposal orbit
  • Jan 24, 1978: Uncontrolled reentry over northern Canada
  • Debris scattered over 124,000 km from Great Slave Lake to northern Alberta/Saskatchewan

Operation Morning Light

  • Joint US-Canadian search and recovery operation
  • 12 large pieces recovered, 10 radioactive
  • Highest readings: 1.1 sieverts/hour
  • Only ~1% of reactor fuel recovered
  • Operation cost: $14 million (Canada billed USSR $6 million, received $3 million)

Policy Consequences

  • Strengthened Outer Space Treaty liability provisions
  • UN principles on nuclear power in space (1992)
  • USSR redesigned safety systems for future satellites
  • International framework for space nuclear liability established
💡

Near Miss

If the satellite had failed one orbit later, debris would have fallen near New York City during morning rush hour.

Radioisotope power has enabled humanity's greatest space exploration achievements.

The Voyager Achievement

Launched in 1977, both Voyagers are still operating more than 47 years later, powered by RTGs now producing about 220 watts (down from 470W). They are 15+ billion miles from Earth, in interstellar space, returning data daily. This is the ultimate proof of radioisotope power reliability.

⚛ Project KRUSTY (2018): The Game-Changer

Kilopower Reactor Using Stirling TechnologY - the first US fission reactor test in over 50 years.

🏆

March 2018: "We threw everything at it"

"We threw everything we could at this reactor, in terms of nominal and off-normal operating scenarios, and KRUSTY passed with flying colors." - David Poston, Chief Reactor Designer, Los Alamos National Laboratory

What Was Tested

  • 28 kg solid uranium-molybdenum alloy core
  • 850C (1,560F) operating temperature
  • ~5.5 kW thermal, ~1 kW electric output
  • Sodium heat pipes for heat transport
  • Stirling engines for power conversion
  • Single control rod for startup/regulation
  • 28-hour full-power test on March 20, 2018

What Was Proven

  • ✔ Reactor starts safely
  • ✔ Operates at steady state
  • ✔ Follows load changes
  • ✔ Shuts down predictably
  • ✔ Survives fault scenarios
  • ✔ Strong negative temperature feedback
  • ✔ Passive safety (gets safer as it heats)

Why KRUSTY Matters

1
Proof of Physics

Demonstrated that small fission reactors can operate safely and stably with passive safety systems.

2
Low Cost Path

Completed in 3 years for less than $20 million - proving space reactors don't require billions.

3
Scalable Design

Kilopower architecture scales from 1 kW to 10 kW - perfect for lunar bases (4-5 units = 40 kW).

KRUSTY's architecture has become the template for modern space reactor development, including what companies like Radiant are building.

Key Design Principles Validated

Heat Pipe Cooling

  • No pumps, no moving parts in primary loop
  • Passive, gravity-independent heat transport
  • Proven to survive nuclear environment

Inherent Safety

  • Negative temperature coefficient
  • Self-regulating (hotter = less reactive)
  • No operator intervention needed

Simple Core

  • Solid fuel (no coolant channels)
  • Single control element
  • Minimal components = reliability

Autonomous Operation

  • Physics-based load following
  • Years of unattended operation
  • Ideal for remote deployments

❌ Cancelled Programs: Lessons from Failure

Space nuclear has been "subject to a remarkable cycle of boom and bust." Understanding past failures helps avoid repeating them.

The most ambitious post-SNAP reactor program, killed by changing priorities and spiraling costs.

Design Goals

  • Power: 100 kWe
  • Thermal: 2 MWt
  • Life: 7 years
  • Conversion: Thermoelectric
  • Coolant: Lithium
  • Heat transport: Heat pipes

Why It Failed

  • Cold War ended - defense missions cancelled
  • Cost overruns and schedule delays
  • No clear mission "customer"
  • Never advanced to flight hardware
  • Triagency management challenges

NASA's most ambitious nuclear spacecraft concept - a 200 kWe reactor to explore Jupiter's icy moons.

Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter (JIMO) Concept

  • Power: 200 kWe nuclear reactor
  • Propulsion: Nuclear electric (ion thrusters)
  • Targets: Orbit Callisto, Ganymede, Europa sequentially
  • Goal: Search for subsurface oceans and life
  • Mission duration: 15-20 years

Why It Failed

  • Budget: $252.6M (2005) $100M (2006, mostly closeout)
  • Total invested before cancellation: ~$464 million
  • Shuttle Columbia disaster refocused NASA priorities
  • Vision for Space Exploration consumed budget
  • Too ambitious without sustained political support
💡

The Lesson

Large flagship missions are vulnerable to budget cycles. Incremental development with clear milestones (like KRUSTY FSP) builds more sustainably than moon-shot programs.

The Pattern

Space nuclear programs have repeatedly fallen into "boom and bust" cycles: big ambitions funding mission creep cost growth cancellation. The programs that succeed (RTGs, KRUSTY) are focused, affordable, and have clear near-term applications.

🌎 The New Space Nuclear Race: 2025 and Beyond

This is a race. Whoever establishes nuclear infrastructure on the Moon first gains strategic advantage for decades.

🇷🇺 🇨🇳 China-Russia Partnership

International Lunar Research Station (ILRS)

  • Target: Nuclear reactor on Moon by 2033-2035
  • 2025: Formal nuclear cooperation agreement signed
  • 2028: Chang'e-8 tests base construction systems
  • Approach: Autonomous robotic construction
  • Russia leads: Nuclear technology (32+ reactor heritage)
  • China leads: Lunar landing, base construction
  • Partners: 13 countries including Pakistan, Venezuela, Belarus
  • 555 Project: 50 countries, 500 institutions, 5,000 researchers

🇺🇸 United States

NASA Fission Surface Power (FSP)

  • Target: Lunar reactor by ~2030
  • 2018: KRUSTY test success
  • 2022: Phase 1 concept contracts awarded
  • 2024: FSP DEEP contracts (Westinghouse, Radiant)
  • Power: 40-100+ kWe class
  • Approach: Commercial partnerships
  • Contractors: Lockheed Martin, IX, Westinghouse, Radiant
  • Also: DARPA DRACO (propulsion), DARPA On-Orbit Power
⚠

The Stakes

Russia's Wu Weiren (chief lunar program designer) stated Russia is "ahead of the United States" in space nuclear deployment. With 33 reactors flown vs America's 1, they have a point. If China-Russia deploys first, they set the standards for lunar infrastructure. NASA's 2030 goal is not just a science target - it's a strategic imperative.

📈 Technology Evolution: Cold War to Present

What's different about modern space reactors compared to the 1960s?

Aspect1960s (SNAP Era)2020s (Modern Era)
Control Ground-commanded, human-in-loop Autonomous, physics-based self-regulation
Safety Philosophy Active safety systems, engineered controls Inherent safety, negative temperature feedback
Cooling Pumped NaK loops (moving parts) Heat pipes (passive, no pumps)
Power Conversion Thermoelectric (~2-3% efficiency) Stirling/Brayton (20-40% efficiency)
Materials Limited high-temp alloys Advanced superalloys, ceramics, composites
Fuel U-ZrH (moderate enrichment) HALEU, advanced TRISO, metal fuels
Modeling Slide rules, limited computing High-fidelity simulation, digital twins
Manufacturing Hand-built, one-off Additive manufacturing, mass production potential
Launch Safety Ad-hoc risk acceptance NSPM-20 framework, structured review

The Key Breakthrough: Passive Safety

Modern reactors like KRUSTY and Radiant's Kaleidos use inherent safety - the physics guarantees safe behavior without operator intervention. If the reactor overheats, it naturally becomes less reactive and cools down. No complex control systems, no risk of runaway. This is the fundamental advance that makes autonomous space reactors possible.

📚 Historical Lessons for Today

What Works

  • RTGs: 45+ units, 60+ years, zero failures in space
  • Simple designs: KRUSTY proved elegance beats complexity
  • Incremental development: Build, test, learn, scale
  • Clear missions: Programs with customers survive
  • Passive safety: Physics-based is more reliable than engineered
  • Affordable scope: $20M KRUSTY > $400M SP-100

What Doesn't

  • Flagship programs: JIMO, SP-100 - too big, too slow
  • No customer: Technology without mission dies
  • Multi-agency limbo: Unclear ownership kills programs
  • Boom-bust cycles: Inconsistent funding wastes investment
  • Complexity: More parts = more failure modes
  • Perfect vs good: Don't let great be enemy of flight
🎯

The Path Forward

The US flew ONE reactor in 1965. The USSR flew 33. The gap is real. But KRUSTY showed modern US capabilities are world-class. The FSP program, DARPA initiatives, and commercial players like Radiant are building on this foundation. The 2030 lunar reactor goal is achievable - if we sustain the momentum.

🌑 NASA-DOE Fission Surface Power (FSP)

The flagship U.S. effort to deploy nuclear power on the Moon by 2030.

🎯

2030 Goal: 100 kWe Lunar Reactor

Updated requirements (2025): 100 kWe output using closed Brayton cycle power conversion. Enough to power 30 homes continuously for 10+ years through lunar nights.

Program Evolution

Nov 2021

Initial RFP Released

Original goal: 40 kWe, max 6 metric tons, "end of decade" launch.

Jun 2022

Phase 1 Contracts Awarded

$5M each to Lockheed Martin (with BWXT, Creare), Westinghouse (with Aerojet Rocketdyne), and IX (Intuitive Machines + X-energy, with Maxar, Boeing).

Nov 2024

FSP DEEP Contracts

Detailed Engineering and Experiment Planning phase. Westinghouse and Radiant selected.

Jan 2025

Westinghouse Continues

NASA/DOE select Westinghouse for continued FSP development.

2025

Requirements Updated

New focus: 100 kWe output, closed Brayton cycle. Streamlined to support commercial providers.

Dec 2025

Second Draft AFPP Posted

Posted to SAM.gov 12/5/25 for industry review. Comments due 12/12/25.

Early 2026

Final AFPP Release Expected

Final solicitation anticipated for Phase 2 / TDU development.

Jul 2025

TDU Public Session

INL and NASA held public info session on Technology Demonstration Unit development and testing solicitation.

Phase 1 Contractors (2022)

  • Lockheed Martin - with BWXT and Creare
  • Westinghouse - with Aerojet Rocketdyne
  • IX - Intuitive Machines + X-energy JV, with Maxar & Boeing

12-month contracts, $5M each

Technical Requirements

  • Power: 100 kWe continuous
  • Conversion: Closed Brayton cycle
  • Life: 10+ years without refueling
  • Operation: Through 14-day lunar nights
  • Deployment: 2030 target

Sources: NASA FSP, INL FSP, ANS Nuclear Newswire

💻 Project Pele - DoD Mobile Microreactor

The Department of Defense's flagship transportable nuclear reactor demonstration.

Technical Specifications

  • Power: 1.5 MWe demonstration
  • Type: Gas-cooled, high-temperature
  • Fuel: TRISO particles (full core delivered Dec 2025)
  • Size: Fits in 4 standard 20-foot shipping containers
  • Transportability: By truck, rail, ship, or aircraft

Contractor Team

  • Prime: BWX Technologies (BWXT)
  • Partners: Northrop Grumman, Rolls-Royce LibertyWorks, Torch Technologies
  • Testing: Idaho National Laboratory
  • Fuel: BWXT Innovation Campus, Lynchburg VA

Reactor components transported to Idaho for assembly.

Announced October 2025, this program will deploy commercially-owned microreactors at Army installations.

📅

"Deploying Advanced Nuclear Reactor Technologies for National Security" - directs DoD to operate an Army-regulated nuclear reactor at a domestic military installation by September 30, 2028.

Nine Candidate Installations (Nov 2025)

  • Fort Benning, GA
  • Fort Bragg, NC

  • Fort Drum, NY

  • Redstone Arsenal, AL
  • + Two additional sites TBD

Program Structure

  • Model: NASA COTS-style milestone payments
  • Ownership: Commercially owned and operated
  • Contracting: DIU Commercial Solutions Opening (CSO) + OTA
  • Power range: kW-level to 20 MWe
  • Fuel: <20% enriched uranium (HALEU)

Related Programs

  • ANPI: Advanced Nuclear Power for Installations (8 companies selected 2025)
  • DOE Pilot: Nuclear Reactor Pilot Program
  • Goal: 3 reactors online by July 4, 2026
  • Participants: Oklo, Radiant among selected companies

Sources: U.S. Army, Breaking Defense

🔬 DARPA Space Nuclear Programs

The Demonstration Rocket for Agile Cislunar Operations program was cancelled in mid-2025 after significant investment.

What It Was

  • Nuclear thermal propulsion demonstration
  • 2-3x efficiency of chemical rockets
  • Mars transit time potentially halved
  • Lockheed Martin prime, BWXT reactor
  • $499M total contract value

Why It Was Cancelled

  • Costs no longer matched benefits
  • Launch cost decreases (SpaceX effect)
  • Analysis showed nuclear electric may be more optimal
  • FY2026 budget provided zero funding
  • Knowledge transferred to NASA

DARPA Deputy Director Rob McHenry: "When DRACO was originally conceived of, that was pre- the precipitous decrease in launch costs that has been driven largely by SpaceX capabilities."

Source: Breaking Defense

Novel approach to convert nuclear radiation directly into electricity without intermediate heat conversion.

  • Concept: Radiovoltaics - direct conversion of radiation energy to electricity
  • Potential: 10-100x improvement in output power per unit mass vs current RTGs
  • Duration: 30-month program in three periods
  • Timeline: Abstracts due Jul 10, 2025; Proposals Aug 20, 2025; Work began Dec 2025

Source: ANS Nuclear Newswire

DARPA TTO is now focusing on producible, cost-effective nuclear reactors rather than one-time demonstrations.

  • Workshop: March 31 - April 1, 2026
  • Partners: DARPA TTO and Department of Energy
  • Goal: Establish common understanding of on-orbit nuclear power technology and challenges
  • Attendance: By invitation based on white paper submissions
  • Focus: Nuclear electric propulsion (more optimal than thermal per new analysis)

Source: DARPA

🌟 The Radiant Master Plan

Why "Radiant"?

"The radiant of a meteor shower is that point in the sky from which all the bright streaks of light appear to originate. The point itself is dark, but from it springs forth everything."

Imagine a time hundreds of years from now when humans have colonized many planets and even other solar systems. To an observer looking at history, humans would appear to have sent bright white shocks of creativity, curiosity, and prosperity out to fill the dark universe. All coming from one pale blue dot: Earth. For civilization itself to achieve its maximum potential, we must be the radiant.

- Doug Bernauer, CEO & Founder

Radiant's mission: mass-produce portable reactors to replace every 1-megawatt diesel generator with an efficient, safe, clean nuclear reactor. Simple to move, operate, shut down, and send back home with their fuel onboard.

💪 The Core Belief

Nuclear energy is as necessary to harness for the advancement of human civilization as fire. It is time to use 100 years of learning in nuclear physics to eradicate myths and replace ignorance with simple truth.

💰 Funding & Backing

$500M+ Total Raised

Series D ($300M+, Dec 2025) + Series C ($165M, May 2025). Venture-backed with significant private capital enabling rapid development independent of government funding cycles.

🚀 Why Radiant in Space: The Origin Story

Space Was Always the Goal

Radiant wasn't founded to build a better diesel generator. It was founded because solar power can't sustain human civilization beyond Earth.

The terrestrial market is the path to get therebut space is where this technology ultimately matters most.

The SpaceX Revelation

The Mars Colonizer Meetings

Doug Bernauer spent 11 years at SpaceX working on projects from mining locomotives to space lasers. During SpaceX's Mars Colonizer meetings, leadership seriously discussed how to establish a permanent Martian settlement.

Bernauer discovered a critical problem: refueling Starship on Mars requires converting ice into methane via the Sabatier reactiona process demanding enormous electrical power.

Why Solar Failed

Initial calculations showed Mars refueling would need over three football fields of solar panelsfar too heavy for Starship's payload capacity. Two separate missions would be required just for the solar infrastructure.

Mars dust storms and unreliable sunlight made solar untenable for critical life-support. When Bernauer presented these findings, "Elon said the word nuclear first."

💡

The Founding Moment

SpaceX had no nuclear expertise. But this didn't deter Bernauerhe stayed at SpaceX for three more years, studying nuclear reactors at night while doing his day job during the day. His conclusion: "After we build Starship, this is the thing to do and build." He left to found Radiant in 2020.

Why Space Demands Nuclear

14 Days
Lunar night with zero sunlight
43%
Less sunlight at Mars vs Earth
2M
Energy density vs solar panels
24/7
Continuous power, any location

⚠ Solar's Space Limitations

  • Lunar nights: 14.5 Earth days of darknessbatteries can't bridge the gap
  • Crater bases: Permanently shadowed regions have water ice but zero sunlight
  • Mars dust: Global dust storms can block sunlight for months
  • Deep space: Jupiter receives 4% of Earth's solar energy; Saturn just 1%
  • Mass penalty: Solar arrays + batteries far exceed nuclear mass for equivalent power

☢ Nuclear's Space Advantages

  • Location-independent: Works in craters, caves, polar regions, anywhere
  • Continuous power: No day/night cycle dependency
  • Compact: 2 million times energy density of chemical fuels
  • Long-duration: Years of operation without refueling
  • Heat bonus: Waste heat provides water extraction and life support

Kaleidos: Designed for Space From Day One

Radiant's Kaleidos reactor isn't a terrestrial design awkwardly adapted for space. Its core features were chosen because they work in space:

Design FeatureTerrestrial BenefitSpace Benefit
Helium coolant Non-activating, no liquid metal handling Works in vacuum, no phase-change issues in zero-g
Compact 1 MW size Portable, fits on trucks Within heavy lander payload limits (15 MT)
5-year fuel cycle Minimal maintenance for remote sites Matches mission timelinesno refueling needed
Passive safety No operators required Autonomous operation on uncrewed missions
TRISO fuel Meltdown-proof safety margins Survives launch vibration, re-entry heating
Waste heat utilization Co-generation, district heating Rodriguez Wells for ice extraction on Mars/Moon
🌍

The Rodriguez Well Concept

Bernauer envisions using reactor waste heat to melt permafrost and create underground water reservoirsa technique proven at Camp Century in 1958, which was powered by a portable nuclear reactor. The same approach works on Mars and the lunar poles.

⚛ Uranium: The Magic Rock

We found a kind of black rocka magic rockthat can unleash two million times the energy that we can get from the highest-density hydrocarbon. These magic rocks tap into the very nature of the Sun itself.

🌌

Where Does Uranium Come From?

Uranium is created when two neutron stars collidea phenomenon we now see about 1-2 times per year in the Milky Way. This "spiciest of stardusts" is jam-packed with energy and exists commonly throughout the Earth in huge quantities. Leaving it in the Earth is wasting a precious resource made billions of years ago by dying stars.

📈 A Case for Every Flavor of Nuclear Power

Different scales serve different needs. Radiant focuses on portable microreactorsthe fastest to deploy and most versatile.

Grid-Scale (1000 MW)

  • First built starting in 1960s
  • US build time: 10-15 years currently
  • South Korea/China: 5-6 years
  • Japan record: 4 years average
  • Market: Tens of units

Small Modular Reactors (50-300 MW)

  • Popularized around 2010
  • More built off-site at factory
  • Shorter onsite construction
  • Timeline: A few years
  • Market: Hundreds of units

Microreactors (5-20 MW)

  • Even shorter onsite timeline
  • Many can be passively cooled
  • Smaller cores, less fuel
  • Timeline: Months
  • Market: Thousands of units

★ Portable Microreactors (1-5 MW)

  • Fully factory-constructed
  • Little to no onsite infrastructure
  • Spent fuel shipped inside reactor
  • Timeline: Weeks
  • This is what Radiant builds

💡 Kaleidos: The Portable Nuclear Generator

Key Features

  • Portable microreactor (shipping-container scale)
  • Factory-constructed, minimal onsite infrastructure
  • Helium gas coolant (can't become radioactive)
  • Zirconium hydride moderator (compact, efficient)
  • TRISO fuel (will not melt down)
  • Passive safety - ambient air cooling
  • Maintained at the factory
  • Dual-use: commercial, military, and space

Development Timeline

  • Fall 2026: DOME facility ready to receive reactor
  • 2027: First reactor testing at INL DOME
  • 2028: First customer delivery
  • 2030: 10+ reactors produced
  • 2034: ~50 reactors/year production

Submitted DOE Authorization Request (DARK) - 45-day approval under new Authorization Pathway.

📈

Mass Production Focus

50 reactors per year is a small figure for some products but certainly considered mass production for nuclear reactors. This focus on cost and designing the reactor as a product differentiates Radiant from traditional approaches.

⚡ The Case: Diesel vs Nuclear for Remote Communities

A remote community of 1,000 people could choose between a 1-megawatt diesel genset or a nuclear genset. Here's what happens over 20 years:

💥 1 MW Diesel Generator

  • 2 million pounds of CO2 emissions
  • ~12 avoidable deaths from diesel exhaust carcinogens
  • People breathe cancer every day
  • Continuous fuel supply chain required
  • Vulnerable to fuel price shocks

☢ 1 MW Nuclear Generator

  • Zero CO2 emissions
  • Zero risk of cancer from emissions
  • Nuclear fuel stays inside reactor
  • Fuel carried away to centralized repository
  • Can be reprocessed for more power

♻ Nuclear Waste: The Real Numbers

Developed societies produce wastea lot. But let's compare how much nuclear waste actually compares to everything else.

26
Metric Tons - Lifetime waste per person globally
0.5
Pounds - Lifetime nuclear waste per person for ALL electricity
💡

That's the Scale

If you generated ALL electricity for one person with current nuclear fission technology, it would create just about half a pound of waste over their entire life. Nuclear waste is extremely easy to detect and compact enough to easily keep stored safely away.

🛡 Nuclear Safety: The Record Speaks

Despite accounting for 18% of US power generation, the primary concern around nuclear continues to be unfounded fear of accidents. But the numbers tell a different story.

US Commercial Nuclear Power Death Toll from Radiation

0 or 1

In the entire history of regulated nuclear power generation in the United States

Radiation Saves Lives

Radiation now saves millions of lives each year through diagnostic imaging and nuclear chemotherapy. These cures and diagnostics are made inside nuclear reactors. If you or a loved one get sick, it is far better to be in a plentiful nuclear world.

Natural Radiation

Your body is emitting 500 gamma rays per second from naturally occurring Potassium-40. It's a required nutrient found in bananas, potatoes, and common foods. Radiation on Earth was higher when humans first evolved than it is now.

🚧 50 Years Without Innovation

No new nuclear design has been approved by the NRC in the US since its inception in 1974. The regulatory process has produced over 440 regulatory documentsprescriptive regulations appearing under the guise of "friendly guidance." For a reactor developer, it's an insurmountable task to put everything published over the last five decades into practice.

💡

What We Need: Re-Regulation

Start from a blank slate, write down all safety risks, and ensure a thorough and critical review process that addresses them all. The point of regulation is to avoid unnecessary risks to the public while minimizing delays that delay prosperity.

The precedent exists: The world's first artificial nuclear reactor in Chicago was built in less than a year. Liberty ships were built faster than any ships ever built at scale. SpaceX sends rocket launches to space every few days. When America needs it, they can make it happen.

📚 Federal Contracting 101: The Complete Overview

Before diving into agency-specific playbooks, you need to understand how federal contracting actually works. This is fundamentally different from commercial sales.

💡 The Core Truth

Defense BD = Create programs, not just chase them.

Smart companies show up early, brief program managers, and submit thoughtful RFI responses that quietly steer requirements toward what they can deliver.

Defense BD vs Commercial Sales

Commercial SalesDefense / Space BD
Quarterly closeMulti-year pursuit
Pricing focusedBudget + policy focused
Buyer = CIO/CTOBuyer = Program Office + Congress
Demo ContractDemo Budget RFP Contract
Short cycleLong cycle (12-36+ months)
Direct negotiationFormal evaluation criteria

🔄 The Real Workflow: How Programs Actually Happen

Programs start with "market research," not contracts. Before money flows, agencies publish signals. Here's the actual sequence:

Step 1

Problem Discovery

BD spends time with operators, program offices, labs, integrators, HQ staff, and congressional staffers. Learning: where power is limiting missions, what's in future plans, what's unfunded but desired, which offices control money.

Step 2

Opportunity Shaping (Pre-Solicitation)

Before anything is released: white papers, technical concept notes, informal briefings, industry days, demonstrations, site visits, workshops. Goal: influence how the government frames the problem. This is called "capture shaping."

Step 3

Pick the Right Contract Path

BD helps steer toward: BAA (open R&D calls), SBIR/STTR (small business), OTA (fast prototyping), or traditional RFP (major procurements).

Step 4

Build Teams

Rarely do startups go alone. BD assembles prime contractors, integrators, national labs, universities, launch providers, test sites. Negotiates teaming agreements, workshare, IP, and margins.

Step 5

Track Budgets & Policy

BD watches: Program Objective Memorandum (POM - 5-year DoD budget), authorization bills, appropriations, Space Force/NASA strategy docs, DOE nuclear programs. Key question: Is money actually coming?

Step 6

Proposal & Capture Execution

When something formal drops: lead capture strategy, write/coordinate proposals, manage win themes, cost story, executive reviews, compliance, red teams.

Step 7

Post-Award Transition

After a win: support contract negotiations, handoff to program managers, keep customer relationships warm, tee up follow-on work.

📜 Contract Vehicles Explained: The Complete Guide

Understanding the difference between contract types is critical. Each has different rules, timelines, and strategies.

⚡ OTA Other Transaction Authority

"Let's skip some red tape so we can prototype cutting-edge tech quickly."

A special contracting mechanism the U.S. government uses to move fast and work with non-traditional companies that might avoid normal federal contracts.

What Makes OTAs Different

  • Much faster: Weeks/months instead of years
  • More flexible: Negotiated terms, custom IP
  • Startup-friendly: Not FAR-compliant
  • Prototype-focused: Demos, test articles, pilots

Common OTA Use Cases

  • Demonstration systems
  • Pilot deployments
  • Early field tests
  • Risk-reduction programs
  • AI, autonomy, nuclear, space power

Who Uses OTAs

DoD labs, Space and missile agencies, Defense innovation offices (DIU), Combatant commands, Rapid-capabilities shops. Common in defense-tech, space power, AI, autonomy, and microreactors.

OTA Proposal Format

  • Technical solution narrative
  • Demo plan with objectives
  • Rough-order cost estimate
  • Schedule (12-24 months typical)
  • Company background & commercial relevance

📜 FAR Federal Acquisition Regulation (Traditional RFPs)

The formal system behind classic government procurements.

Used across DoD and NASA for major programs. Heavy compliance burden but stable funding for multi-year programs.

How FAR Works

  • Government publishes detailed RFP
  • Months to prepare proposals
  • Formal evaluation criteria
  • Audits, certifications, cost reviews
  • Protestable awards (losers can sue)

Typical Use Cases

  • Weapon systems
  • Satellites
  • Nuclear plants
  • Large IT systems
  • Production contracts

Pros

  • Stable multi-year funding
  • Big production contracts
  • Clear path to Programs of Record

Cons

  • Slow (12-36+ months)
  • Heavy compliance burden
  • Tough for startups
  • Expensive proposal process

🔬 BAA Broad Agency Announcement

R&D shops like DARPA use these for early-stage research and demonstrations.

BAA Characteristics

  • Rolling submissions
  • White papers first (5-8 pages)
  • If invited: full proposal (30-60 pages)
  • Competitive but startup-friendly
  • FAR-lite (less regulated)

What They Fund

  • Science & tech exploration
  • Early-stage research
  • Demonstrations
  • Phase 1/2/3 structured programs

Typical BAA Format

  • Technical area descriptions
  • Research goals & metrics
  • Expected funding ranges by phase
  • Evaluation criteria
  • Submission portal & deadlines

🔍 RFI Request for Information

Market research not contracts yet, but they shape future RFPs!

Agencies are testing the market: Who can do this? How mature is the tech? What approaches exist? What would it cost?

Typical RFI Contains

  • Background / mission need
  • Problem statement
  • Desired capabilities
  • Rough performance targets
  • Questions to industry
  • Instructions & due date

What You Submit (5-15 pages)

  • White-paper style PDF
  • High-level concept
  • Team description
  • Risks & mitigations
  • No pricing usually required
💡

Pro Tip: RFIs Shape RFPs

Smart companies treat RFI responses like mini proposals. Your input influences requirements. Steer them toward what you can deliver.

🚀 CSO Commercial Solutions Opening (DIU's OTA)

Buy commercial or near-commercial tech quickly. Award in 60-90 days.

CSO Format

  • Mission problem statement
  • Desired capability
  • Performance thresholds
  • Demo scope & timeline
  • Transition target

What You Submit

  • 5-10 page solution brief
  • Pitch-deck style PDF
  • Cost estimate
  • Company traction/revenue

Reality: VC-backed startups love these. DIU pre-identifies transition partners.

🎓 SBIR/STTR Small Business Innovation Research

Government-wide innovation grants. Great entry point for startups.

PhasePurposeAward SizeDuration
Phase IFeasibility study$50K - $275K6-12 months
Phase IIPrototype development$750K - $1.7M24 months
Phase IIICommercializationNon-SBIR fundsVaries

Pros

  • Non-dilutive funding
  • Great for startups
  • Builds credibility
  • Multiple agencies participate

Cons

  • Slow process
  • Competitive
  • Not guaranteed to become production

📋 IDIQ Indefinite Delivery / Indefinite Quantity

Umbrella vehicles that pre-qualify vendors, then issue fast task orders.

How IDIQ Works

  • Painful to get on initially
  • Once on: fast task orders
  • Pre-negotiated terms
  • Multi-year contracts

Common Use Cases

  • IT services
  • Engineering support
  • Sustainment
  • Advisory services

🤝 CRADA Cooperative R&D Agreement

Partnership with national labs. Essential for reactor companies.

Private firms partner with DOE labs (INL, ORNL, LANL) to test fuel forms, run safety analysis, irradiate materials, qualify components, and support launch licensing.

Reality: DOE lab relationships are existential for reactor companies. Any real reactor touches DOE facilities.

💰 Contract Payment Structures: How Money Actually Flows

Beyond the contract vehicle (OTA, BAA, FAR), the payment structure determines how you get paid, how much risk you take, and how easily a program can be cancelled. This is critical for startups.

💡 Why Payment Structure Matters

The same contract vehicle (e.g., FAR) can have completely different payment structures. A cost-plus FAR contract works nothing like a fixed-price milestone FAR contract. Understanding this distinction separates sophisticated BD from amateur hour.

🎯 Milestone-Based Contracts (DOE Style)

Payment tied to achieving specific technical milestones. The gold standard for nuclear development.

How It Works

  • Contract defines specific technical milestones
  • Payment released when milestone achieved
  • Built-in oversight: govt reviews each milestone
  • Progress is objectively measurable
  • Both parties aligned on outcomes, not activities

Example Milestones

  • Preliminary Design Review (PDR)
  • Critical Design Review (CDR)
  • First fuel fabrication
  • Non-nuclear prototype complete
  • Safety analysis submitted
  • Initial criticality achieved
💡

Real Example: Kairos Power & DOE

DOE awarded Kairos Power a milestone-based contract for Hermes reactor development. Each payment is tied to achieving specific technical gates. Kairos can't just burn through cashthey have to deliver results. DOE gets built-in oversight without micromanaging daily work. This structure helped Kairos become one of the most credible advanced reactor companies.

Why Milestone-Based is Superior

  • Hard to cancel: Progress is visible and measurable
  • Built-in accountability: No milestone = no payment
  • Aligned incentives: Both parties want same outcomes
  • Protects taxpayers: Money follows results
  • Protects contractor: Clear deliverables, less scope creep

Challenges

  • Requires well-defined milestones upfront
  • Less flexibility if scope changes
  • Contractor bears schedule risk
  • Needs mature enough technology to plan milestones

🚀 COTS Commercial Orbital Transportation Services

Fixed-price, milestone-driven, minimal government oversight. How NASA enabled SpaceX.

How COTS Works

  • Fixed-price: Contractor bids total cost upfront
  • Milestone payments: Pay for results, not effort
  • Minimal oversight: Govt doesn't manage day-to-day
  • Contractor autonomy: Company decides HOW to achieve goals
  • Private investment required: Contractor has skin in game

COTS vs Traditional

  • Traditional: Govt specifies exactly how to build
  • COTS: Govt specifies what capability needed
  • Traditional: Govt owns everything
  • COTS: Contractor keeps IP, can sell commercially
  • Traditional: Cost-plus means open checkbook
  • COTS: Fixed price means contractor eats overruns
🚀

The SpaceX Example

NASA's COTS program gave SpaceX $396M in milestone payments to develop Falcon 9 and Dragon. SpaceX invested ~$450M of their own money. Total program cost: ~$850M. Traditional cost-plus approach would have cost $4-12B. SpaceX kept the IP, now sells launches commercially, and NASA gets cheaper access to space. Win-win.

Pros

  • Dramatically lower cost to government
  • Faster development (less bureaucracy)
  • Contractor keeps IP commercial market
  • Innovation incentivized (better margins if efficient)
  • Creates sustainable commercial capability

Cons

  • Contractor bears all cost overrun risk
  • Requires private capital (not all can raise)
  • Less government control over design
  • Program failure = contractor failure (no bailout)
  • Needs commercially viable end market

Space Nuclear Relevance: A COTS-style approach for lunar reactors could dramatically reduce costs. Radiant's commercial focus and private funding make it a natural fit for this model.

📈 Cost-Plus / Cost-Based Contracts (Traditional)

Government reimburses all costs plus a fee. The traditional model for major defense programs.

How Cost-Plus Works

  • Government reimburses all allowable costs
  • Contractor gets fee (typically 8-15%)
  • Requires extensive cost accounting (DCAA audits)
  • Government bears cost overrun risk
  • Detailed government oversight of spending

Cost-Plus Variants

  • CPFF: Cost Plus Fixed Fee
  • CPIF: Cost Plus Incentive Fee
  • CPAF: Cost Plus Award Fee
  • T&M: Time & Materials (similar concept)

When Cost-Plus is Used

  • High technical uncertainty (can't estimate costs)
  • R&D with unknown outcomes
  • First-of-a-kind systems
  • When government needs tight control over design
  • Programs where failure risk is high

Pros

  • Low financial risk for contractor
  • Easier to get started (less upfront capital)
  • Flexibility to change scope
  • Appropriate for true R&D

Cons (The Big Problems)

  • Easy to cancel: Govt can walk away anytime
  • Cost overruns: No incentive to be efficient
  • Schedule slips: Delays just mean more billing
  • Heavy oversight: Govt in your business daily
  • Compliance burden: DCAA audits, FAR requirements
⚠

The Cancellation Problem

Cost-plus contracts can be terminated at government convenience with little penalty. Programs like DRACO got cancelled despite years of work. Milestone-based contracts create more "stickiness" because visible progress makes cancellation politically harder.

Contract Structure Comparison

Factor Milestone-Based COTS (Fixed-Price) Cost-Plus
Payment Trigger Technical milestones achieved Milestones + fixed total Costs incurred + fee
Cost Overrun Risk Shared Contractor bears all Government bears all
Cancellation Risk Lower (visible progress) Lower (private investment) Higher (easy to walk away)
Government Oversight Moderate (milestone reviews) Minimal Heavy (daily involvement)
IP Ownership Negotiable Contractor keeps Usually government
Private Capital Required Some Significant Minimal
Best For Nuclear development, demos Commercial space, mature tech Pure R&D, unknowns
Example DOE + Kairos Power NASA COTS + SpaceX Traditional defense programs

💡 Strategic Insight for Radiant

Radiant's positioncommercially funded, building a real product, with private investmentmakes it ideal for milestone-based or COTS-style contracts. Push for these structures over cost-plus. The combination of visible technical progress and private skin-in-the-game makes programs much harder to cancel and creates better alignment with agency goals.

🔍 What Agencies Actually Evaluate

Across DARPA, Space Force, NASA, and DOE, proposals rise or fall on these criteria:

Universal Evaluation Criteria

  • Clear mission relevance
  • Technical novelty + realism
  • Credible scaling path
  • Safety and regulatory awareness
  • Test infrastructure access
  • Team pedigree
  • Schedule discipline
  • Transition plan to operational use

Nuclear-Specific Must-Haves

  • DOE lab access/partnerships
  • Fuel pathway understanding
  • Launch-safety literacy
  • Export-control awareness
  • Named nuclear engineers on team
  • Non-nuclear prototype data
  • Regulatory pathway knowledge
  • Safety analysis experience

The Winning Statement

"We've already raised private money and built a non-nuclear prototype."

Agencies love this because it de-risks their investment.

📝 Contract Formats: What You Actually Submit

Understanding the format determines your success. Each vehicle has different requirements.

RFI Response (5-15 pages)

Market research shapes future RFPs

  1. Executive Summary (1-2 paragraphs)
  2. Mission Applications
  3. Technical Approach
  4. Development Plan
  5. Safety & Launch Considerations
  6. Teaming Strategy
  7. Cost ROM
  8. Why Your Team

BAA White Paper (5-8 pages)

R&D funding invitation to full proposal

  1. Problem Statement
  2. Technical Approach
  3. Key Innovations
  4. Team (named individuals)
  5. Risks & Mitigations
  6. Schedule & Cost ROM

OTA Proposal (15-30 pages)

Fast prototyping without FAR compliance

  1. Technical Solution
  2. Prototype Plan
  3. Demo Objectives
  4. Schedule with Milestones
  5. Cost Breakdown
  6. IP/Data Rights
  7. Transition Path

Full FAR Proposal (60+ pages)

Traditional procurement heavy compliance

  1. Technical Volume (detailed approach)
  2. Management Volume (org, schedule)
  3. Past Performance Volume
  4. Cost Volume (detailed pricing)
  5. Compliance Matrix
  6. Certifications & Reps
💡

Pro Tip: RFIs Shape RFPs

Smart companies treat RFI responses like mini proposals. Your input influences how the government frames requirements. Steer them toward what you can deliver.

🎯 Practical Tips: How New Entrants Actually Break In

Most successful companies do NOT start by trying to win a $500M prime contract. Here's the actual path:

1. Pick a Niche

  • Fuel fabrication
  • Thermal management
  • Shielding
  • Power conversion
  • Controls / autonomy
  • Heat pipes

2. Build Credibility

  • Win small SBIRs first
  • Partner with a national lab
  • Build non-nuclear prototypes
  • Publish technical papers
  • Get named nuclear engineers

3. Team Smart

  • Prime on small contracts
  • Sub to big primes on large ones
  • Sign MOUs early
  • Don't compete with your partners

4. Be Everywhere

  • Respond to every relevant RFI
  • Attend every Industry Day
  • Brief every PM who will listen
  • Get in working groups

The Goal

"Force future programs to assume a Radiant-class reactor."

If Phase 0/1 goes well, Phase 2 becomes inevitable.

📚 Space Nuclear BD Glossary
