All Showing

📜 Contract & Acquisition Terms

Federal contracting terminology essential for space nuclear business development.

RFI
Request for Information - Government market research tool used to gather information about industry capabilities before issuing a formal solicitation. Responding shapes future RFPs but doesn't result in a contract.
RFP
Request for Proposal - Formal solicitation asking for detailed technical and cost proposals. Results in competitive evaluation and contract award to the best-value offeror.
RFQ
Request for Quote - Solicitation for pricing on specific items or services. Typically used for commercial items where technical requirements are well-defined.
BAA
Broad Agency Announcement - Open solicitation for basic and applied R&D proposals. Typically requires white paper submission first, then invitation for full proposal. Not for specific systems.
OTA
Other Transaction Authority - Flexible contracting mechanism outside FAR regulations. Enables fast prototyping (weeks vs years), negotiable IP terms, and startup-friendly processes. Key for defense-tech.
CSO
Commercial Solutions Opening - DIU's streamlined OTA variant for rapid commercial technology acquisition. 60-90 day award timeline typical. Focus on existing commercial solutions.
FAR
Federal Acquisition Regulation - Primary regulation governing federal procurement. Establishes uniform policies for supplies and services acquisition. Complex compliance burden but stable funding.
DFARS
Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement - DoD-specific supplement to FAR with additional requirements for defense contracts including cybersecurity (CMMC), export controls, and cost accounting.
IDIQ
Indefinite Delivery/Indefinite Quantity - Contract vehicle establishing a pre-qualified vendor pool. Task orders issued against IDIQ for specific work. Reduces procurement time for repeat needs.
BPA
Blanket Purchase Agreement - Simplified method for filling anticipated repetitive needs for supplies or services. Establishes pricing and terms for future orders.
GWAC
Government-Wide Acquisition Contract - Multiple-award IDIQ contracts available to all federal agencies. Primarily for IT products and services. Examples: SEWP, CIO-SP3.
SBIR
Small Business Innovation Research - Competitive R&D funding for small businesses. Phase I: feasibility ($50-275K, 6 months). Phase II: development ($750K-1.5M, 24 months). Phase III: commercialization (unlimited).
STTR
Small Business Technology Transfer - Like SBIR but requires partnership with a research institution (university or federal lab). Research institution must perform at least 30% of Phase I, 40% of Phase II.
CRADA
Cooperative Research and Development Agreement - Partnership mechanism between federal labs and private companies. No funds exchanged; lab provides facilities/expertise, company provides resources. Flexible IP sharing.
SAM
System for Award Management - Official government database for vendor registration. Required for all federal contracts. Must maintain active registration with current CAGE code and banking info.
CAGE Code
Commercial and Government Entity Code - Five-character identifier for companies doing business with federal government. Required for SAM registration and all contract documentation.
UEI
Unique Entity Identifier - Replaced DUNS number in 2022. 12-character alphanumeric ID assigned by SAM.gov for all entities doing business with the federal government.
SOW
Statement of Work - Contract document specifying all work requirements for a contractor. Defines deliverables, milestones, acceptance criteria. Prescriptive approach - tells contractor how to do the work.
PWS
Performance Work Statement - Describes required results in measurable outcomes rather than methods. Gives contractor flexibility on how to achieve objectives. Preferred for services acquisition.
SOO
Statement of Objectives - High-level document stating overall performance objectives. Maximum flexibility for innovative solutions. Offerors develop their own PWS/SOW in proposals.
CLIN
Contract Line Item Number - Standard identifier for deliverables on defense contracts. Four-digit number (e.g., 0001) breaks contract into discrete items for pricing and tracking.
FFP
Firm Fixed Price - Contract type where price is set and not subject to adjustment. Contractor bears full cost risk. Used when requirements are well-defined and risk is manageable.
CPFF
Cost Plus Fixed Fee - Government pays allowable costs plus negotiated fixed fee. Used for R&D when costs are uncertain. Requires certified cost accounting system.
CPIF
Cost Plus Incentive Fee - Like CPFF but fee varies based on cost performance against target. Incentivizes cost control while sharing risk between government and contractor.
T&M
Time and Materials - Payment based on labor hours at fixed rates plus materials at cost. Used when scope is uncertain. Requires close government oversight.
LPTA
Lowest Price Technically Acceptable - Evaluation method where contract goes to lowest-priced offeror meeting minimum requirements. Used for commodities, not complex R&D.
TRL
Technology Readiness Level - 1-9 scale measuring technology maturity. TRL 1: basic principles. TRL 6: prototype demo. TRL 9: mission-proven. Critical metric in all proposals.
MRL
Manufacturing Readiness Level - 1-10 scale assessing production readiness. MRL 4: proof of concept. MRL 6: prototype capability. MRL 8: pilot line ready. Complements TRL.
CRL
Commercial Readiness Level - Measures market readiness and commercialization potential. Increasingly used by DOE and ARPA-E to assess transition likelihood.
Pwin
Probability of Win - Capture management metric estimating likelihood of winning a specific opportunity. Based on customer relationship, technical fit, price position, and competitive analysis.
LRIP
Low-Rate Initial Production - Limited production to verify manufacturing processes before full-rate production. Typically follows successful developmental testing. Usually MRL 8+.
CO
Contracting Officer - Government official with authority to award, administer, and terminate contracts. Only the CO can obligate government funds or modify contracts.
COR
Contracting Officer's Representative - Technical expert designated to monitor contractor performance. Cannot modify contract terms but provides technical direction within scope.
PM
Program Manager - Government official responsible for overall program execution. Key relationship for BD - influences requirements and funding decisions.
TPOC
Technical Point of Contact - Government technical expert for a specific solicitation. Primary contact during proposal development for technical questions.

🏢 Agency & Organization Acronyms

Government agencies, military branches, and key organizations in the space nuclear ecosystem.

NASA
National Aeronautics and Space Administration - Civilian space agency. Key offices: STMD (Space Technology), ESDMD (Exploration Systems), Glenn Research Center (nuclear power lead).
DOE
Department of Energy - Oversees nuclear technology, national labs, and HALEU production. Office of Nuclear Energy (NE) manages reactor programs. Key partner for all space nuclear.
DoD
Department of Defense - Largest federal agency. Includes Army, Navy, Air Force, Space Force, and defense agencies. Multiple nuclear power programs (Pele, Janus, JETSON).
DARPA
Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency - High-risk, high-reward R&D. Tactical Technology Office (TTO) handles space/nuclear. Known for game-changing programs. 3-5 year project cycles.
USSF
United States Space Force - Newest military branch (est. 2019). Responsible for space operations, satellite defense, and cislunar domain awareness. Under Department of the Air Force.
SSC
Space Systems Command - USSF field command managing space acquisition, launch, and sustainment. Located at Los Angeles AFB. Manages NSSL and space nuclear programs.
SDA
Space Development Agency - DoD agency building proliferated LEO satellite constellations. Under Space Force since 2022. Focus on resilient space architecture.
NRO
National Reconnaissance Office - Intelligence agency operating reconnaissance satellites. Works with Space Force on launches. Potential customer for high-power space systems.
AFRL
Air Force Research Laboratory - Air Force/Space Force R&D organization. Space Vehicles Directorate (RV) leads JETSON nuclear power program. Key customer for space nuclear.
DIU
Defense Innovation Unit - DoD organization for rapid commercial tech adoption. Uses CSO (Commercial Solutions Opening) for fast contracting. Startup-friendly, Silicon Valley presence.
SpaceWERX
Space Force Innovation Arm - USSF's component of AFWERX. Manages Space Force SBIR/STTR, Primes, and innovation challenges. Key entry point for space nuclear startups.
AFWERX
Air Force Innovation Arm - Manages SBIR/STTR, Primes, and challenges. SpaceWERX is the Space Force component. Good entry point for defense-tech companies.
SCO
Strategic Capabilities Office - DoD office accelerating deployment of existing tech in new ways. Reports directly to SecDef. Pursues near-term operational advantages.
NRC
Nuclear Regulatory Commission - Independent agency regulating civilian nuclear materials and reactors. Does NOT regulate DoD or NASA space nuclear - see INSRB instead.
NNSA
National Nuclear Security Administration - Semi-autonomous DOE agency managing nuclear weapons stockpile and naval reactors. Controls weapons-grade materials and certain HALEU pathways.
INL
Idaho National Laboratory - DOE's lead nuclear R&D lab. Houses DOME test facility, ATR test reactor, and TREAT transient testing. Essential partner for reactor testing.
ORNL
Oak Ridge National Laboratory - DOE lab with extensive nuclear expertise. HALEU processing, fuel fabrication, and materials research. Radiant's Oak Ridge factory nearby.
ANL
Argonne National Laboratory - DOE lab near Chicago. Nuclear reactor design, simulation, and analysis expertise. Important for modeling and safety analysis support.
LANL
Los Alamos National Laboratory - DOE/NNSA lab. Nuclear weapons expertise, plutonium science, and heat source production for RTGs. Key for nuclear materials.
SNL
Sandia National Laboratories - DOE/NNSA lab managed by Honeywell. Nuclear safety, power conversion, and systems engineering. KRUSTY testing partner.
PNNL
Pacific Northwest National Laboratory - DOE lab in Washington state. Nuclear materials, nonproliferation, and environmental cleanup expertise.
JPL
Jet Propulsion Laboratory - NASA center managed by Caltech. Leads robotic planetary missions. Extensive RTG mission experience (Mars rovers, Voyager).
GRC
Glenn Research Center - NASA center in Cleveland. Leads Fission Surface Power program and space power research. Primary NASA contact for nuclear power.
MSFC
Marshall Space Flight Center - NASA center in Huntsville. Propulsion systems expertise. Led DRACO nuclear thermal propulsion (cancelled) and SLS development.
TTO
Tactical Technology Office - DARPA office managing space, tactical systems, and advanced platforms. Handles space nuclear programs like DRACO (cancelled) and Rads to Watts.
STMD
Space Technology Mission Directorate - NASA organization funding technology development. Manages FSP, nuclear propulsion studies, and technology demonstration missions.
ESDMD
Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate - NASA organization managing Artemis program including SLS, Orion, Gateway, and lunar surface systems.
OSTP
Office of Science and Technology Policy - White House office advising President on science/tech. Coordinates interagency space nuclear policy. Issued NSPM-20.
NSC
National Security Council - White House body coordinating national security policy. Involved in space nuclear launch approvals for sensitive missions.

🚀 Program Names & Initiatives

Active, historical, and international space nuclear programs and initiatives.

FSP
Fission Surface Power - NASA-DOE program to deploy 100 kWe nuclear reactor on Moon by 2030. Closed Brayton cycle. Phase 2 contracts to Lockheed and Westinghouse. Key opportunity.
DOME
Demonstration of Microreactor Experiments - INL test facility for microreactor demonstrations. Construction complete March 2026. Radiant's Kaleidos testing scheduled for 2027.
Project Pele
DoD Mobile Microreactor - Army/DOE program for 1-5 MW transportable reactor. BWXT building prototype. Operational deadline September 2028 per EO 14299.
Janus
Army Microreactor Program - Plan to deploy microreactors at 9 military bases. Named for two-faced Roman god (power + heat). EO 14299 deadline September 2028.
JETSON
Joint Emergent Technology Supplying On-Orbit Nuclear Power - AFRL/Space Force program for nuclear electric spacecraft power. $33.7M contract to Lockheed Martin. High-power ISR focus.
DRACO
Demonstration Rocket for Agile Cislunar Operations - DARPA nuclear thermal propulsion program. CANCELLED June 2025 due to cost/benefit analysis vs. SpaceX's reduced launch costs.
Rads to Watts
DARPA Direct Conversion Program - Research into direct radiation-to-electricity conversion without thermal cycle. Potentially enables ultra-compact space power. Active R&D.
Artemis
NASA Lunar Exploration Program - Return humans to Moon, establish sustained presence. Artemis III: first landing. Base Camp requires nuclear power for 14-day lunar nights.
Gateway
Lunar Gateway Station - NASA-led space station in lunar orbit. Staging point for lunar surface missions. Power and Propulsion Element uses solar, but surface ops need nuclear.
ILRS
International Lunar Research Station - China-Russia joint lunar base. Nuclear reactor planned 2033-2035. Direct competitor to Artemis. Key driver for US space nuclear urgency.
KRUSTY
Kilopower Reactor Using Stirling Technology - 2018 demonstration at Nevada NNSS. 1-10 kWe prototype proved compact fission power feasible. Foundation for FSP program.
Kilopower
NASA Compact Fission Concept - 1-10 kWe reactor design using HEU fuel, Stirling conversion. KRUSTY was the demonstration. Basis for some FSP concepts.
SNAP
Systems for Nuclear Auxiliary Power - 1955-1973 program. SNAP-10A: only US fission reactor launched (1965). SNAP-3 through SNAP-27: RTG heritage. Foundation of space nuclear.
SNAP-10A
First US Space Reactor - Launched April 1965. 500 We thermoelectric. Operated 43 days before communications lost. Still in orbit. Only US fission reactor ever launched.
SP-100
Space Power 100 kWe - 1983-1994 joint NASA/DOE/DoD program. Advanced space reactor concept. Cancelled due to end of Cold War and budget constraints. $500M spent.
Prometheus/JIMO
Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter - 2002-2005 NASA nuclear electric mission concept. Would have orbited Callisto, Ganymede, Europa. Cancelled due to cost ($16B estimate).
TOPAZ
Soviet/Russian Space Reactor - Thermionic conversion reactors. TOPAZ-II tested at Sandia 1992-1995. More advanced than contemporary US designs. 5-40 kWe range.
RORSAT/BES-5
Soviet Radar Ocean Reconnaissance Satellites - USSR launched 31 nuclear reactors 1970-1988. Powered by BES-5 (Buk) reactors. Kosmos 954 re-entry incident (1978).
MARVEL
Microreactor Applications Research Validation and Evaluation - INL program demonstrating microreactor at lab facilities. First US microreactor demo since 1960s. Supports Pele and commercial reactors.
MAGNET
Microreactor Agile Non-Nuclear Experimental Test Bed - INL facility for microreactor component testing without nuclear fuel. Enables rapid iteration and de-risking.
Oracle
AFRL Cislunar Awareness Spacecraft - Space Force mission for tracking objects between Earth and Moon. Supports Artemis and planetary defense. Demonstrates cislunar domain awareness.
NSSL
National Security Space Launch - DoD program for launching national security payloads. Phase 3 contracts to ULA and SpaceX. May be needed for future space reactor launches.
EO 14299
Executive Order on Microreactors - Trump administration order directing DoD microreactor deployment by September 2028. Establishes legal deadline for Pele and Janus.

☢ Nuclear Technology Terms

Nuclear reactor, fuel, and safety terminology essential for understanding space nuclear systems.

HALEU
High-Assay Low-Enriched Uranium - Uranium enriched 5-20% U-235. Required for most advanced reactors. Enables smaller, more efficient designs. Limited US supply - key bottleneck. Not weapons-grade (<20%).
LEU
Low-Enriched Uranium - Uranium with <20% U-235. Commercial reactors use 3-5% LEU. HALEU is a subset (5-20%). Cannot be used for weapons without further enrichment.
HEU
Highly Enriched Uranium - Uranium with 20% U-235 (typically 90%+ for weapons/naval). KRUSTY used HEU. New designs targeting HALEU to avoid proliferation concerns.
TRISO
Tri-structural Isotropic Fuel - Fuel particles <1mm with uranium kernel surrounded by carbon/ceramic layers. Withstands extreme temps without melting. Cannot release radioactivity. Meltdown-proof.
CERMET
Ceramic-Metal Fuel - Uranium oxide in tungsten or molybdenum matrix. Excellent high-temperature performance. Used in nuclear thermal propulsion designs. Alternative to TRISO for some applications.
UN Fuel
Uranium Nitride Fuel - High-density fuel form. Higher thermal conductivity than oxide. Promising for compact space reactors. Used in some advanced designs.
U-235
Uranium-235 - Fissile isotope of uranium. Only naturally occurring fissile material. 0.7% of natural uranium. Must be enriched for reactor use.
U-238
Uranium-238 - Dominant uranium isotope (99.3%). Not fissile but fertile - can absorb neutron to become plutonium. Provides some power in reactors.
Criticality
Self-Sustaining Chain Reaction - Condition where fission chain reaction maintains itself. Each fission produces enough neutrons for another fission. "Critical" = stable operation, not an accident.
Subcritical
Chain Reaction Declining - Neutron population decreasing. Reactor power falling. Safe shutdown condition. Fuel alone is always subcritical without proper geometry.
Supercritical
Chain Reaction Growing - Neutron population increasing. Used briefly during startup to raise power. Controlled supercriticality is normal operation, not an accident.
Moderator
Neutron Slowing Material - Slows fast neutrons to thermal energies for efficient fission. Water, graphite, beryllium, or zirconium hydride. Radiant uses ZrH2 (zirconium hydride).
ZrH2
Zirconium Hydride - Radiant's moderator material. Compact, efficient neutron moderation. Enables smaller reactor cores. Key differentiator in their design.
Coolant
Heat Transfer Fluid - Removes heat from reactor core. Options: water, helium, sodium, lead, molten salt. Radiant uses helium - inert, can't become radioactive, works in space vacuum.
Reflector
Neutron Bouncing Material - Surrounds core to reflect escaping neutrons back. Improves fuel efficiency. Beryllium or graphite common. Drum reflectors can control criticality.
Control Rod
Reactivity Control Device - Neutron-absorbing material inserted into core to control power. Inserting rods reduces power; withdrawing increases. Primary shutdown mechanism.
Control Drum
Rotating Reflector Control - Cylindrical reflector with absorber on one side. Rotating toward core increases reactivity. Common in space reactor designs. No penetrations into core.
Heat Pipe
Passive Heat Transfer Device - Sealed tube with working fluid. Evaporates at hot end, condenses at cold end, wicks back. Extremely reliable, no moving parts. Used in KRUSTY.
kWe
Kilowatts Electric - Electrical power output. What you actually use. FSP targets 100 kWe. Radiant targets ~1,000 kWe (1 MWe). Always less than thermal due to conversion efficiency.
kWt
Kilowatts Thermal - Total heat energy from reactor. Larger than kWe due to conversion losses. 100 kWe might require 400-500 kWt depending on efficiency. Waste heat must be rejected.
MWe
Megawatts Electric - 1,000 kWe. Radiant's Kaleidos targets ~1 MWe. Large commercial reactors: 1,000+ MWe. Space nuclear currently focused on 100 kWe - 1 MWe range.
Decay Heat
Residual Radioactive Heat - Heat from radioactive decay of fission products after shutdown. Can't be turned off. Requires cooling even after reactor stops. Passive systems essential.
Fission Products
Nuclear Waste from Splitting - Radioactive elements created when uranium splits. Main source of radiation in spent fuel. Decay over time - most active isotopes short-lived.
Burnup
Fuel Utilization Measure - Energy extracted per unit fuel, typically MWd/kg. Higher burnup = more efficient fuel use. TRISO enables high burnup without failure.
Passive Safety
Inherent Safe Shutdown - Reactor shuts down automatically via physics without operator action or powered systems. Negative temperature coefficient: hotter = less reactive = self-limiting.
Shadow Shielding
Directional Radiation Protection - Shield positioned between reactor and payload/crew. Doesn't surround entire reactor - reduces mass. Uses geometry and distance for protection.
Containment
Radioactive Material Barrier - Multiple barriers preventing release: fuel form, cladding, vessel, structure. TRISO provides containment at particle level. No release even in accidents.

🌏 Space & Propulsion Terms

Space mission, propulsion, and power conversion terminology for nuclear applications.

NTP
Nuclear Thermal Propulsion - Reactor heats propellant (hydrogen) directly for thrust. ~900s Isp (2 chemical). High thrust + high efficiency. DRACO was demonstrator (cancelled).
NEP
Nuclear Electric Propulsion - Reactor generates electricity for ion/plasma thrusters. Very high Isp (3000-5000s) but low thrust. Best for long-duration cargo missions.
Bimodal NTP
Dual-Mode Nuclear Propulsion - Single reactor provides both NTP thrust and NEP electrical power. Thrust for fast transits, electricity for coast phase. Maximizes capability per mass.
RTG
Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generator - Uses Pu-238 decay heat with thermocouples for electricity. Low power (100-300 We) but extremely reliable. Voyager, Cassini, Mars rovers. Not a reactor.
RHU
Radioisotope Heater Unit - Small Pu-238 device providing heat only (no electricity). Keeps electronics warm in cold environments. 1 watt thermal each. Used throughout spacecraft.
MMRTG
Multi-Mission RTG - Current US RTG design. ~110 We at beginning of life. Used on Curiosity, Perseverance, Dragonfly. Pu-238 supply is limited.
Isp
Specific Impulse - Propulsion efficiency measure (seconds). Higher = more efficient. Chemical: 450s. NTP: 900s. NEP: 3000-5000s. Ion: 3000+s.
Delta-V
Velocity Change Budget - Total velocity change needed for a mission. Determines propellant requirements. Higher Isp = less propellant for same delta-v.
Stirling Conversion
Piston Heat Engine - Closed-cycle engine using gas expansion/compression. 25-30% efficiency. Used in KRUSTY. Good for 1-10 kWe range. Moving parts = reliability concern.
Brayton Cycle
Gas Turbine Conversion - Closed-loop turbine using gas (He, Xe-He mix). 20-25% efficiency. Scalable to MW range. NASA FSP baseline. Higher power than Stirling.
Thermoelectric
Direct Heat-to-Electricity - Solid-state conversion via Seebeck effect. No moving parts, extremely reliable. Low efficiency (5-7%). Used in RTGs. Good for low power, long life.
Thermionic
Hot Electron Emission - Electrons "boil off" hot surface, collected at cooler electrode. 10-15% efficiency. Soviet TOPAZ used this. Higher efficiency than thermoelectric.
Radiator
Waste Heat Rejection - Large panels radiating waste heat to space via Stefan-Boltzmann law. Major mass driver - 100 kWe may need 50+ m radiator area. Limits power density.
ISRU
In-Situ Resource Utilization - Using local resources (lunar ice, Martian CO2) instead of bringing from Earth. Requires significant power - nuclear enables ISRU at scale.
Sabatier Reaction
Mars Fuel Production - CO2 + H2 CH4 + H2O. Makes methane from Martian atmosphere for Starship refueling. Requires ~100 kW scale power. Nuclear ideal for this.
Rodriguez Well
Ice Melting Technique - Use heat to melt permafrost, creating underground water reservoir. Proven at Camp Century (1958) with nuclear. Applicable to Moon/Mars poles.
Cislunar
Earth-Moon Space - Region between Earth and Moon including lunar orbit. Strategic domain for military and commercial. Nuclear power enables sustained cislunar operations.
LEO
Low Earth Orbit - 200-2000 km altitude. Most satellites operate here. ISS is at ~400 km. Nuclear generally not needed for LEO - solar works fine.
GEO
Geosynchronous/Geostationary Orbit - 35,786 km altitude. Satellites appear stationary over Earth. Communications, weather. Solar works but nuclear enables higher power.
HEO
Highly Elliptical Orbit - Elongated orbit, often for northern hemisphere coverage. Long dwell time at apogee. Nuclear useful for extended eclipse tolerance.
Lunar Night
14.5 Earth Days of Darkness - No sunlight for power or warmth. Solar arrays useless, batteries insufficient. Nuclear essential for permanent lunar bases.
PSR
Permanently Shadowed Region - Crater areas near lunar poles with zero sunlight ever. Contain water ice. Nuclear required - solar impossible. Prime mining targets.
NRHO
Near Rectilinear Halo Orbit - Stable orbit around Moon for Gateway station. Highly elliptical, passes over lunar poles. Enables surface access with minimal delta-v.
L1/L2 Lagrange
Gravitational Balance Points - Locations where gravitational forces balance. Earth-Moon L2 behind Moon. Sun-Earth L2 used by JWST. Strategic for cislunar operations.

💰 Policy, Budget & Regulatory Terms

Government policy, budget process, and regulatory terminology affecting space nuclear programs.

NSPM-20
National Security Presidential Memorandum 20 - 2019 policy establishing tiered launch approval framework for space nuclear. Created INSRB. Streamlined process for lower-risk systems.
INSRB
Interagency Nuclear Safety Review Board - Standing board reviewing space nuclear launch safety. Replaced ad-hoc INSRP panels. Coordinates DOE, NASA, DoD, EPA safety reviews.
INSRP
Interagency Nuclear Safety Review Panel - Historical ad-hoc panels for mission-specific safety review. Replaced by permanent INSRB under NSPM-20. Each RTG mission had its own INSRP.
Launch Approval
Authorization to Launch Nuclear - Required for all space nuclear systems. Three tiers under NSPM-20: agency head, interagency, or Presidential depending on risk level.
SAR
Safety Analysis Report - Comprehensive document analyzing all accident scenarios and consequences. Required for launch approval. Demonstrates acceptable risk levels.
NEPA
National Environmental Policy Act - Requires environmental impact assessment for federal actions. Space nuclear launches need Environmental Impact Statements or Environmental Assessments.
EIS
Environmental Impact Statement - Detailed environmental analysis required for major federal actions. Space nuclear typically requires EIS due to potential radiological impact.
POM
Program Objective Memorandum - DoD's 5-year budget planning document. Submitted annually. Key indicator of program priorities. Space nuclear programs need POM inclusion for stability.
PPBE
Planning, Programming, Budgeting, Execution - DoD budget process cycle. Programs compete for resources through this process. Understanding PPBE critical for BD timing.
NDAA
National Defense Authorization Act - Annual law authorizing DoD programs and spending levels. Often includes space nuclear policy provisions. Must be enacted for programs to proceed.
Appropriations
Actual Funding Allocation - Separate from authorization. Congress must appropriate funds for programs to receive money. Authorization without appropriation = no funding.
CR
Continuing Resolution - Temporary funding when appropriations not passed. Maintains previous year levels. Prevents new program starts. Common budget uncertainty.
RDT&E
Research, Development, Test & Evaluation - DoD budget category for R&D. Most space nuclear funding here. Separate from procurement (buying production units).
FFRDC
Federally Funded Research and Development Center - Government-sponsored R&D organizations. National labs (INL, ORNL, etc.) are FFRDCs. Special contracting rules apply.
GOCO
Government-Owned, Contractor-Operated - Facility ownership model. National labs are GOCO - government owns, contractors (Battelle, UT-Battelle, etc.) operate.
ITAR
International Traffic in Arms Regulations - Export controls on defense articles including space technology. Nuclear space systems typically ITAR-controlled. Limits international collaboration.
EAR
Export Administration Regulations - Commerce Dept export controls for dual-use items. Some nuclear technology under EAR. Less restrictive than ITAR but still requires licenses.
Part 810
DOE Nuclear Export Controls - 10 CFR 810 controls export of nuclear technology and assistance. Specific authorization required for sharing reactor technology internationally.
QA/QC
Quality Assurance/Quality Control - Rigorous processes required for nuclear components. NQA-1 standard for nuclear. Adds cost but ensures reliability and safety.
NQA-1
Nuclear Quality Assurance Standard - ASME standard for nuclear facility quality programs. Required for DOE nuclear work. Establishes documentation, testing, and traceability requirements.
CMMC
Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification - DoD cybersecurity requirement for contractors. Level 2+ typically required for space nuclear work. Must be certified before contract award.
Space Policy Directive
Presidential Space Policy - Executive directives on space priorities. SPD-6 (2020) established space nuclear power/propulsion as national priority. Key policy foundation.

⚖ Space Nuclear Policy Overview

The U.S. space nuclear regulatory framework involves multiple agencies with overlapping jurisdictions. Understanding this landscape is critical for Radiant's BD strategy.

Key Takeaway for Radiant

Space nuclear is NOT regulated by the NRC for government missions. The launch approval process goes through the INSRB under NSPM-20, with DOE providing safety analysis. This is a fundamentally different (and faster) path than commercial terrestrial licensing.

Primary Regulatory Bodies

  • INSRB: Interagency launch approval
  • DOE: Safety analysis, nuclear materials
  • NASA: Civilian mission authority
  • FAA: Commercial launch licensing
  • DoD: Military mission authority
  • NRC: Terrestrial commercial only

Key Policy Documents

  • NSPM-20: Launch approval framework
  • SPD-6: National strategy for SNPP
  • EO 14299: DoD microreactor mandate
  • ADVANCE Act: NRC modernization
  • December 2025 EO: Space superiority

🎯 Executive Orders & Presidential Directives

Presidential actions establishing U.S. space nuclear policy priorities and implementation requirements.

🌟 "Ensuring American Space Superiority" (December 2025)

NEW

Signed: December 18, 2025 by President Trump

Establishes revised framework for U.S. space operations with specific nuclear power mandates:

  • Lunar reactor by 2030: Deploy nuclear reactor on Moon surface
  • 60-day deadline: APST must issue National Initiative for American Space Nuclear Power guidance
  • Revokes National Space Council - APST (Michael Kratsios) now leads implementation
  • Enables nuclear reactors both on Moon and in orbit
Official Document →

💻 Executive Order 14299 - DoD Microreactor Deployment

MANDATE

Signed: May 23, 2025 by President Trump

Directs DoD to deploy advanced nuclear reactor at domestic military installation:

  • Deadline: Operational by September 30, 2028 (end of FY28)
  • Army designated Executive Agent for DoD nuclear energy (Janus Program)
  • Establishes program of record for installation and operational nuclear energy
  • Project Pele prototype must achieve criticality before July 4, 2026
Official Document →

☢ Executive Order 14300 - NRC Reform

Signed: May 23, 2025 by President Trump

  • 18-month deadline for new reactor licensing decisions
  • 12-month deadline for license renewals
  • Expedited pathway for DOE/DoD-tested reactor designs
  • High-volume licensing process for microreactors and modular reactors
  • Standardized applications and approvals allowed
Official Document →

🚀 Space Policy Directive-6 (SPD-6) - National SNPP Strategy

Signed: December 16, 2020 by President Trump

Establishes national strategy for Space Nuclear Power and Propulsion (SNPP):

  • Goal 1: Develop fuel production capabilities by mid-2020s for RTGs to NTP/NEP
  • Goal 2: Demonstrate 40+ kWe fission surface power on Moon by mid-to-late 2020s
  • Goal 3: Develop NTP system for human Mars missions
  • Sustained lunar presence and Mars exploration as key objectives
Official Document →

🛡 NSPM-20 - Launch Approval Framework

Signed: August 20, 2019 by President Trump

Modernized space nuclear launch authorization process:

  • Created INSRB: Permanent board replaces ad-hoc panels
  • Tiered approval: Risk-based approach (Tier I-III)
  • Safety guidelines: Dose-based metrics for launch authorization
  • Commercial guidance: First framework addressing commercial launches
  • Early engagement between safety evaluators and mission designers
NRC Summary →

🚀 Space Nuclear Launch Approval Framework (NSPM-20)

The tiered approval process established by NSPM-20 for launching spacecraft containing nuclear systems.

💡

Why This Matters for Radiant

Understanding the NSPM-20 tier your mission falls into determines the approval timeline, documentation requirements, and which agency has launch authority. Lower tiers = faster approvals.

The Tiered Approval System

TierRisk LevelApproval AuthorityRequirements
Tier I Low risk, small quantities Sponsoring agency head Simplified safety analysis, no INSRB SER required
Tier II Moderate risk Sponsoring agency head + INSRB review Full SAR, INSRB Safety Evaluation Report (SER)
Tier III Highest risk Presidential authorization Full SAR, INSRB SER, NSC coordination

INSRB - Interagency Nuclear Safety Review Board

Member Agencies (7 total)

  • Department of Defense
  • Department of Energy
  • Department of State
  • Department of Transportation
  • Environmental Protection Agency
  • NASA
  • Nuclear Regulatory Commission

INSRB Responsibilities

  • Review quality of mission safety analyses
  • Conduct independent safety evaluations
  • Prepare Safety Evaluation Reports (SER)
  • Inform launch authority decision-makers
  • Maintain standard operating procedures

Tier Determination Factors

  • Material-at-risk: Type and quantity of radioactive material
  • Technology maturity: Heritage systems vs. new designs
  • Radiological risk: Dose estimates from safety analysis
  • Accident probability: Likelihood of release scenarios
  • Mission profile: Launch trajectory, orbital insertion, potential re-entry

Final tier determination occurs after completion of nuclear safety analysis.

☢ NRC & DOE Regulatory Authority

Understanding which agency has jurisdiction is critical - space nuclear follows a different path than commercial terrestrial.

⚠ Key Distinction

NRC does NOT license government space nuclear missions. Space nuclear for NASA/DoD missions is authorized through the INSRB process under NSPM-20, with DOE providing safety analysis.

NRC jurisdiction applies to: (1) commercial terrestrial reactors, (2) potentially commercial space nuclear if not for government mission.

Jurisdictional Framework

ScenarioRegulatory AuthorityProcess
NASA space mission (FSP) INSRB + NASA NSPM-20 tiered approval
DoD space/terrestrial mission DoD (Army) + DOE EO 14299, Army regulation
DOE site testing (DOME) DOE authorization DOE Order 425.1 / 426.2
Commercial terrestrial NRC 10 CFR Part 50/52/53
Commercial space (private) TBD - likely FAA + INSRB Evolving framework

NRC Part 53 - Advanced Reactor Framework

Status & Timeline

  • Proposed Rule Published: October 31, 2024
  • Comment Period Closed: February 28, 2025
  • Draft Final to Commission: May 1, 2026
  • Final Rule Expected: End of 2027

Key Features of Part 53

  • Technology-inclusive: Works for any reactor type
  • Risk-informed: Uses PRA-led approach
  • Performance-based: Outcomes over prescriptive requirements
  • Cost savings: $53-68M per applicant vs. current process

DOE Authorization Pathway

For testing at DOE sites (like Radiant at DOME), DOE has its own authorization process:

  • DOE Order 425.1: Startup and restart of nuclear facilities
  • DOE Order 426.2: Personnel selection, training, qualification
  • Expedited pathway: EO 14300 establishes NRC-DOE coordination for tested designs
  • DARK: Radiant submitted DOE Authorization Request under new pathway

🌍 NEPA Environmental Requirements

National Environmental Policy Act requirements for space nuclear missions and DOE activities.

NEPA Analysis Levels

Categorical Exclusion (CATEX)

Actions with no significant environmental impact. Fastest path - no detailed analysis required.

New DOE CATEX for advanced reactors effective Feb 2, 2026

Environmental Assessment (EA)

Concise analysis for actions that may or may not have significant impacts. Results in FONSI or triggers EIS.

Environmental Impact Statement (EIS)

Full detailed analysis for major federal actions. Required when significant environmental impacts likely.

Space Nuclear NEPA Considerations

NASA Nuclear NEPA Handbook (2024)

NASA published comprehensive guidance for NEPA practitioners on space nuclear missions:

  • Launch accident scenarios and probability analysis
  • When EIS is required vs. EA sufficient
  • Balancing probability against consequences
  • DOE/NASA coordination for accident modeling
Download Handbook →
💡

New DOE Categorical Exclusion (Feb 2026)

DOE established new CATEX for "authorization, siting, construction, operation, reauthorization, and decommissioning of advanced nuclear reactors" - significantly streamlining NEPA for microreactors.

🛡 Safety Analysis Process

The rigorous safety documentation required for space nuclear launch approval.

Safety Analysis Report Progression

PSAR

Preliminary Safety Analysis Report

Early design phase. Identifies potential hazards and preliminary risk estimates. Submitted early for INSRB feedback.

USAR

Updated Safety Analysis Report

Design maturity increases. Refined accident scenarios and consequence analysis. Incorporates INSRB comments.

FSAR

Final Safety Analysis Report

Complete analysis with final design. Basis for INSRB Safety Evaluation Report (SER) and launch authority decision.

Mission Phases Analyzed

PhaseDescriptionRisk Contribution
PrelaunchGround handling, fueling, pad operationsLow
Early LaunchLiftoff through max-Q, high propellant load~99% of total risk
Late LaunchUpper stage burns, orbital insertionModerate
Suborbital ReentryIf launch fails before orbit achievedVariable
Orbital ReentryPlanned or unplanned deorbitLow-Moderate
Long-term ReentryOrbital decay over years/decadesLow

Key Safety Analysis Components

Accident Model Document (AMD)

  • Potential accident scenarios
  • Hardware response to accident environments
  • Source terms (curies released, particle sizes)
  • Release probabilities

Nuclear Risk Analysis Document (NRAD)

  • Maximum individual dose estimates
  • Collective dose calculations
  • Health effects projections
  • Land contamination area estimates

Primary Contractor: Sandia National Laboratories leads space nuclear launch safety analysis (MSL 2011, Mars 2020 FSAR).

🚨 Radiological Emergency Response

Federal coordination framework for radiological incidents, including space nuclear accidents.

Key Response Organizations

NIRT - Nuclear Incident Response Team

Established by Homeland Security Act of 2002. Activated by DHS/FEMA for nuclear/radiological incidents.

  • 13 DOE/NNSA and EPA specialized assets
  • Operates under FEMA coordination
  • Deployable within hours

FRMAC - Federal Radiological Monitoring

Interagency consortium providing monitoring and assessment during radiological incidents.

  • Verifies radiation measurements
  • Interprets radiation distributions
  • Characterizes overall conditions

Coordination Framework

FRPCC - Federal Radiological Preparedness Coordinating Committee

National-level forum for radiological policy coordination. Chaired by DHS/FEMA. Established 1982 under 44 CFR 351. Develops policies and procedures supporting state, tribal, and local emergency planning.

💡

NASA/DOE-Specific Response

If Initial Response Force (IRF) deployed at DOE or NASA request as custodial agencies for radiological materials, IRF coordinates with DOE or NASA incident commander on-site.

💰 Liability & Insurance Framework

Financial protection mechanisms for nuclear incidents and space launch activities.

Price-Anderson Act

Overview

Enacted 1957, most recently extended to December 31, 2065. Establishes no-fault insurance system for nuclear incidents.

$16.6B
DOE contractor liability limit (2023 adj.)
$500M
Primary insurance per reactor site

Commercial Space Launch Insurance

FAA-Licensed Launches

Commercial Space Launch Act Amendments (1988) - modeled on Price-Anderson:

  • MPL Insurance: Based on FAA Maximum Probable Loss calculation
  • Statutory ceiling: $500M or max available at reasonable cost
  • Government indemnification: Additional $2.7B (inflation-adjusted) subject to Congressional appropriation
⚠

Evolving Framework for Space Nuclear

Existing Price-Anderson provisions were designed for terrestrial, LEU-fueled large reactors. GAO has noted the $1.5B indemnification cap may be insufficient for growing commercial space launch volume. Framework for commercial space nuclear is still evolving.

NASA Indemnification Authority

Under 51 U.S. Code 20148, NASA contracts may provide U.S. indemnification for providers against third-party claims for death, injury, or property damage from launch services that are "unusually hazardous or nuclear in nature."

🌐 International Framework (UN/COPUOS)

International treaties and principles governing the use of nuclear power sources in outer space.

Key International Instruments

Outer Space Treaty (1967)

Foundation of international space law. Key provisions:

  • Prohibits weapons of mass destruction in space
  • Limits celestial body use to peaceful purposes
  • Mandates space exploration for benefit of all countries
  • Does NOT prohibit nuclear power sources - only nuclear weapons

Principles on Nuclear Power Sources in Space (1992)

UN General Assembly adopted voluntary guidelines following 1978 Kosmos 954 incident (Soviet reactor re-entry over Canada):

  • Pre-launch safety assessment requirements
  • Notification to UN Secretary-General
  • Dissemination of safety information to other states
  • Voluntary, not legally binding
UNOOSA Principles →

Safety Framework for NPS Applications (2009)

Joint COPUOS/IAEA framework providing high-level guidance:

  • Programmatic and technical safety aspects
  • Design and application guidance
  • Voluntary, not legally binding
  • 2023 report recommends enhancements for new 5-year workplan
🌎

U.S. Position

The U.S. has 30+ space nuclear missions over 60 years. U.S. government position: the Principles and Safety Framework provide comprehensive foundation for safe use of nuclear power in space. U.S. actively participates in COPUOS Working Group on NPS.

🔒 Export Controls & Technology Transfer

Three overlapping regulatory regimes govern export of nuclear and space technology.

RegulationAgencyScopeSpace Nuclear Impact
10 CFR Part 810 DOE/NNSA Unclassified nuclear technology transfer Reactor design, nuclear assistance to foreign entities
ITAR (22 CFR 120-130) State Dept (DDTC) Defense articles, space launch vehicles, some spacecraft Launch vehicle integration, remote sensing
EAR (15 CFR 730-774) Commerce (BIS) Dual-use items and technologies Non-military components, commercial items

10 CFR Part 810 Details

What Part 810 Controls

  • Transfer of unclassified nuclear technology overseas
  • Transfer to foreign nationals anywhere (including in U.S.)
  • Technical assistance and technical data
  • Does NOT control: Classified information, nuclear propulsion technology, equipment/material exports

Authorization Types

  • Generally Authorized: Transfers to Appendix A countries (allies)
  • Specific Authorization: Required for non-Appendix A countries
  • Always Requires Specific Auth: Sensitive nuclear technologies (enrichment, reprocessing, plutonium fuel, heavy water production)
DOE Part 810 Information →
⚠

Radiant Implications

Space reactor technology likely falls under multiple regulatory regimes. International collaboration, foreign investors, or foreign national employees may require coordination between DOE, State, and Commerce. Consult export control counsel early.

📜 Key Legislation

Congressional acts shaping the space nuclear regulatory and funding landscape.

ADVANCE Act of 2024

Jul 2024

Accelerating Deployment of Versatile, Advanced Nuclear for Clean Energy Act

  • Bipartisan NRC modernization legislation
  • 18-month deadline for NRC microreactor guidance
  • Eliminates pre-application costs at DOE sites
  • Expedites military microreactor projects (Eielson AFB by 2027)
  • Efficient, timely, predictable license reviews
NRC ADVANCE Act Info →

NEIMA - Nuclear Energy Innovation and Modernization Act

Jan 2019
  • Required NRC to establish technology-inclusive framework
  • Basis for Part 53 rulemaking
  • Final rule deadline: end of 2027

NDAA FY2024 - Nuclear Fuel Security Act

Dec 2023
  • Creates Nuclear Fuel Security Program
  • LEU contracts: 100 MT/year by Dec 31, 2026
  • HALEU contracts: 20 MT/year by Dec 31, 2027
  • Addresses domestic fuel supply chain gaps

NDAA FY2026 - International Nuclear Energy Act

Dec 2025
  • Section 8366: Supports U.S. civil nuclear industry abroad
  • Nuclear Export Working Group established
  • 10-year civil nuclear trade strategy development
  • Interagency cooperation and funding

Price-Anderson Extension

Mar 2024
  • Further Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2024
  • Extended Price-Anderson to December 31, 2065
  • 40-year extension for newly licensed reactors

🤝 Interagency Agreements

Key memoranda of understanding and interagency coordination mechanisms.

NASA-DOE MOU on Fission Surface Power (2025)

Renewed commitment to lunar reactor development:

  • Goal: Lunar surface reactor operational by 2030
  • Joint development, fueling, authorization, and deployment
  • Safe, efficient, abundant power for years without refueling
  • Builds on 2016 and 2020 MOUs
NASA Announcement →

DOE-NRC MOU Addendum (May 2025)

Implementing EO 14299-14302:

  • DOE proceeds with non-commercial demonstrations
  • Information sharing to facilitate NRC future licensing
  • Expedited pathway for DOE/DoD-tested designs
  • Roles, responsibilities, and process defined

🎯 Policy Implications for Radiant BD

How the policy landscape creates opportunities and constraints for Radiant's space nuclear strategy.

✓ Favorable Policy Winds

  • 2030 lunar reactor mandate creates urgent timeline
  • DoD September 2028 deadline accelerates microreactor deployment
  • DOME at DOE avoids NRC for initial testing
  • NSPM-20 tiered approach potentially faster approvals
  • ADVANCE Act streamlines future commercial path
  • New DOE CATEX simplifies NEPA for advanced reactors

⚠ Key Considerations

  • FSP Phase 1 participants have head start (Lockheed, Westinghouse)
  • HALEU supply still constrained despite legislation
  • Commercial space nuclear framework still evolving
  • Export controls may limit international partnerships
  • Safety analysis for new reactor designs is extensive

Strategic Recommendations

  1. Leverage DOME testing - DOE authorization path avoids NRC timeline
  2. Engage INSRB early - NSPM-20 encourages pre-launch safety coordination
  3. Track FSP Phase 2 - Position for teaming or follow-on opportunities
  4. Monitor EO implementation - 60-day APST guidance creates near-term windows
  5. Build DOE relationships - Safety analysis expertise at Sandia, INL essential
  6. Prepare for commercial path - Part 53 and ADVANCE Act define future terrestrial market

Latest developments in space nuclear and advanced reactor programs. Updated regularly.

📅 January 2026

HOT Jan 15, 2026

Congress Passes FY2026 Energy Funding: $3.1B for Nuclear

Senate passes bipartisan Energy and Water Development appropriations (82 votes). Includes $3.1B for Office of Nuclear Energy, Advanced Reactor Deployment Program, and up to two Gen3+ SMR development awards.

Holland & Knight Analysis →
KEY Jan 13, 2026

NASA-DOE Sign MOU: Lunar Reactor by 2030

NASA and DOE formalize commitment to deploy fission surface power on Moon by 2030. Agreement advances President's space superiority vision. Reactor will provide continuous power for years without refueling.

NASA Press Release →
HALEU Jan 2026

DOE Awards $2.7B for Domestic Uranium Enrichment

Historic investment to strengthen domestic LEU and HALEU supply chains. American Centrifuge Operating, General Matter, and Orano Federal Services each receive $900M. Additional $28M to Global Laser Enrichment for next-gen technology.

DOE Announcement →
HALEU Jan 27, 2026

Westinghouse & Nuclear Transport Solutions Partner on HALEU Transport

Companies to co-develop transport package for high-assay low-enriched uranium, addressing critical supply chain gap for advanced reactors including eVinci microreactor.

ANS Nuclear Newswire →

RADIANT Dec 17, 2025

Radiant Raises $300M+ Series D at $1.8B Valuation

Led by Draper Associates and Boost VC, with Founders Fund, ARK, and Chevron. Total raised now $518M+. Funds Oak Ridge factory groundbreaking and DOME test preparation for summer 2026.

Radiant Announcement →
POLICY Dec 18, 2025

Executive Order: "Ensuring American Space Superiority"

President Trump signs EO establishing strategic framework for U.S. space leadership. Key goals: astronauts to Moon by 2028, lunar outpost construction by 2030, lunar nuclear reactor by 2030, nuclear reactors in orbit.

Holland & Knight Analysis →
SMR Dec 2025

DOE Selects TVA & Holtec for $800M SMR Deployment

Tennessee Valley Authority and Holtec Government Services selected to support early Gen3+ light-water SMR deployments in Tennessee and Michigan. Combined federal cost-share up to $800M.

INTUITIVE Oct 2025

Intuitive Machines Wins $8.2M AFRL Nuclear Power Contract Extension

U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory extends contract to develop next-gen nuclear power systems for spacecraft and lunar infrastructure. Builds on earlier $9.5M Stirling-based power conversion work.

Intuitive Machines IR →
NuScale Sep 2025

TVA-ENTRA1 Partner on 6 GW of NuScale SMRs

Tennessee Valley Authority signs landmark agreement with NuScale partner ENTRA1 Energy to deploy up to 6 GW of SMR capacity. ENTRA1 to finance, own, and operate plants; TVA to purchase output.

ANS Nuclear Newswire →
DOD Sep 2025

Project Pele Construction Begins at Idaho National Lab

Department of Defense breaks ground on mobile microreactor demonstration. BWXT begins core fabrication. TRISO fuel delivered. On track for 2027 testing and 2028 operation per EO 14299 mandate.

DOE Announcement →
RADIANT Aug 2025

Radiant Signs DIU/Air Force Agreement

Defense Innovation Unit and Department of the Air Force contract with Radiant for microreactor development, expanding company's defense portfolio alongside existing commercial pipeline.

Radiant Blog →
BWXT Aug 2025

BWXT Begins Building Pele Microreactor Core

BWX Technologies commences reactor core fabrication at Lynchburg Innovation Campus. Partners include Rolls-Royce LibertyWorks, Northrop Grumman, and Torch Technologies. Shipment to INL planned for 2026.

ANS Nuclear Newswire →
CANCELLED Jun 2025

DARPA Cancels DRACO Nuclear Thermal Propulsion Program

Program terminated due to declining ROI. DARPA Deputy Director McHenry cites falling launch costs (SpaceX/Starship) and underestimated ground testing challenges. FY2026 budget allocates zero funding for NTP/NEP.

SpaceNews →
CHINA-RUSSIA May 2025

China-Russia Sign Lunar Nuclear Reactor MoU

During ILRS summit in Shanghai, China and Russia formalize plans for joint lunar nuclear power plant by 2035-2036. 17 countries and 50+ institutions now part of ILRS. Roscosmos contracts Lavochkin Association.

South China Morning Post →

World's first microreactor test facility nears completion at INL. Westinghouse eVinci and Radiant Kaleidos selected as first experiments. Defense Production Act authorization expedites construction.

NRC approves Principal Design Criteria Topical Report for eVinci microreactor. Milestone provides clear licensing pathway and streamlines customer adoption. Manufacturing targeted for 2029.

Penn State to Host Westinghouse eVinci Research Reactor

🌎 Global Nuclear Developments

International policy shifts and competitive landscape updates.

🇨🇳 China-Russia ILRS

  • Lunar nuclear reactor by 2035-2036
  • 17 countries, 50+ institutions in ILRS
  • Russia leads nuclear, China leads landing
  • Chang'e-8 (2028) to test systems

🇪🇺 European Union

  • 81.2 GW nuclear capacity by 2040
  • Belgium reversed phase-out plans
  • Italy lifted nuclear ban
  • Germany recognizes nuclear as green

🇮🇳 India

  • Parliament amends nuclear liability law
  • Private sector investment now allowed
  • Major expansion of domestic program

🏴 Global Finance

  • World Bank now allows nuclear lending
  • Asia Development Bank policy updated
  • ~15 reactors to come online in 2026
  • 12 GW capacity additions expected
